results.input_text: Nickel is a promising platform for developing practical fluoroalkylation methodologies as fundamental steps relevant to chemical bond forming reactions have been established. Reductive eliminations involving fluoroalkyl groups have been demonstrated at higher valent states of nickel,[1, 2, 3, 4] the generation of fluoroalkyl radicals via electron transfer or atom abstraction reactions of fluoroalkyl electrophiles with nickel is known,[5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12] fluoroalkyl-based transmetalating reagents readily react with nickel,[13, 14, 15] and catalytic transformations involving select fluoroalkyl groups have been reported.[16, 17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 10, 22, 6] Nickel is also an earth-abundant metal with a reasonably low cost. However, most of the aforementioned chemical transformations involving fluoroalkyl groups required nickel to bear stabilizing ligands other than solvent. While in many cases ligands can serve to tune and enable the reactivity of a nickel center, in other cases they can prevent catalysis through redistributions that affect the speciation of an active form of the nickel catalyst. Moreover, extraneous non-solvento ligands raise the cost of a chemical process and can even contribute to the air-sensitivity of the system. Given these considerations, we became interested in developing new fluoroalkylation methods with nickel that employed solvent as theonly coordinating ligand. Such reaction conditions have commonly been referred to as "ligandless" conditions in other systems.[22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27, 28]

results.input_text: Another way to show the role of the Ln/An 5/6\(p\) orbitals in ITI is to assess the reduction of the electron repulsion of these semi-core electrons in the complex with respect to the free-ion. Within ligand field theory (LFT) the one-electron inter-electronic repulsion integrals are described by the Slater-Condon parameters F\({}^{\text{k}}\)(nl,nl) (n = shell, l = _s,p,d,f_) and the spin-orbit coupling parameter \(\zeta_{\text{nl}}\).[76, 77] Previous studies have successfully applied a non-empirical method to obtain these parameters using a ligand-field DFT (LFDFT) capable of predicting the electronic structure of lanthanide complexes.[78, 79, 80, 81, 45] Since the reductions of the Slater-Condon parameters with respect to the free-ion are related to the central-field and symmetry-restricted covalency, their evaluation will provide further insight into the nature of ITI in these complexes.
results.output_text: A different formulation that highlights the function of the Ln/An 5/6\(p\) orbitals in inner-sphere thermally induced isomerism is to analyze the decrease of electron-electron repulsion for these semi-core electrons in the complex versus the free-ion, as described through ligand field theory (LFT) with Slater-Condon parameters F\({}^{\text{k}}\)(nl,nl). These one-electron integrals characterize inter-electronic repulsion, whereas spin-orbit coupling is measured through the parameter \(\zeta_{\text{nl}}\) in both theory and experiment. A non-empirical ligand-field DFT (LFDFT) capable of predicting the electronic structure of lanthanide complexes has successfully been utilized to study these parameters in previous studies. By quantifying the reductions in these Slater-Condon parameters between the complex and the free-ion, the role of central-field and symmetry-restricted covalency in ITI can be further illuminated.

results.input_text: Dynamic covalent gels have been synthesized from an aromatic trialdehyde and \(\alpha\),\(\omega\)-dinitroalkanes via the nitroaldol reaction in organic solvents. The gelation process could be finetuned by changing the starting nitroalkanes, solvents, feed concentration, catalyst loading, or reaction temperature. The resulting organogels demonstrated good structural integrity and excellent self-healing ability. Intact xerogels were produced upon drying, without damaging the network, and the solvent-free network could recover its gel form in the presence of an organic solvent. Furthermore, the crosslinked dynameric gel depolymerized to small molecules in response to excess nitromethane.
results.output_text: Arromatic trialdehyde and \(\alpha\),\(\omega\)-dinitroalkanes have been utilized in the synthesis of covalent gels via nitroaldol reaction in solvents. Variations in the starting nitroalkanes, solvents, feed concentration, catalyst loadings, and reaction temperatures enable fine-tuning of the gelation process. The resulting dynamic organogels exhibited high structural integrity and exceptional self-healing properties. Upon drying, solvent-free networks were generated without damaging the gel structure. The dynamically crosslinked gels could recover their gel form in the presence of an organic solvent. The crosslinked gel also underwent depolymerization in response to a considerable excess of nitromethane, leading to the conversion of the gel to smaller molecular structures.

results.input_text: Our previous studies have revealed the high efficiency of the nitroaldol (Henry) reaction in generating linear dynamers with reversible C-C bonds [1, 5]. These polymers have demonstrated excellent dynamicity and intricate topological changes in response to the applied conditions. However, the application of the nitroaldol reaction in the formation of more complex polymer systems has not been extensively explored. This is, however, of great importance, since this approach would give rise to new types of functional materials based on dynamic and stimuli-responsive C-C bonds, and raises the prospect of addressing challenges of conventional crosslinked polymers [47, 48]. In the present study, we have addressed the feasibility of constructing crosslinked dynamers through the nitroaldol reaction and investigated the properties of the resulting materials. We thus report the crosslinking and gelation of an aromatic trialdehyde with different \(\alpha\),\(\omega\)-dinitroalkanes in organic solvents. The gelation process was examined through chemical and mechanical approaches, and the effects on the gelation were investigated. Moreover, the responsive behavior of the organogels, including self-healing and degradation, are also demonstrated.
results.output_text: In prior investigations, we have identified that the nitroaldol (Henry) reaction provides a highly efficient mechanism for fabricating linear, reversible polymeric materials with substantial dynamic capabilities [1, 5]. These linear dynamers have demonstrated impressive dynamic behavior and sophisticated architectural transformations in response to environmental influences. Nonetheless, there has been minimal study exploring the applicability of the nitroaldol reaction for generating more complex polymer systems. Due to this gap in knowledge, new categories of functional materials based on dynamic and stimuli-responsive C-C bonds that can tackle the challenges of traditional crosslinked polymers are yet to be realized [47, 48]. Consequently, this investigation aims to ascertain the feasibility of crosslinking linear dynamers using the nitroaldol reaction and investigating the properties of the newly-derived materials. The process of crosslinking and gelation is studied via combined chemical and mechanical evaluations, and the impact on the final results is examined. Furthermore, we demonstrate the exceptional responsive behavior of the material, including self-healing and degradation properties.

results.output_text:
The nitroaldol-crosslinked network polymer exhibited notable stability, as evidenced by its insolubility in water following removal of DMSO and triethylamine. When repeatedly immersed in deionized water, the gel structure remained largely intact despite becoming more opaque and brittle. This process also terminated the reversible nitroaldol reaction and ultimately preserved the crosslinked polymer network. These findings suggest the robustness of the nitroaldol-crosslinked network and provide potential applications in absorption. Additionally, once dry, the network polymer could be analyzed without interference from other gel contents. Remarkably, upon the dry network polymer's exposure to DMSO, the xerogel structure was capable of rapidly absorbing the solvent and reforming the gel in minutes, although with some associated deformation. In conclusion, these results underscore the nitroaldol-crosslinked network polymer's inherent strength and demonstrate its potential utility in absorption applications.

results.input_text: These results showcase a proof-of-concept for dynamic polymer crosslinking using the nitroaldol reaction. This constitutes a new approach to responsive and adaptive network structures, especially self-healable, degradable and recyclable three-dimensional materials. results.input_text: The correct interpretation of the result from a point-of-care device is crucial for an accurate and rapid diagnosis and to guide subsequent treatment. Lateral flow tests (LFTs) use a well-established format that was designed to simplify the user experience. However, the LFT device architecture is inherently limited to detecting analytes that can be captured by molecular recognition. Microfluidic paper-based analytical devices (\(\upmu\)PADs), like LFTs, have the potential to be used in diagnostic applications at the point of care. However, \(\upmu\)PADs have not gained significant traction outside of academic laboratories, in part, because they have often demonstrated a lack of homogeneous shape or color in signal outputs, which consequently can lead to inaccurate interpretation of results by users. Here, we demonstrate a new class of \(\upmu\)PADs that generate colorimetric signals at the interfaces of converging liquid fronts (i.e., lines) to control where colorimetric signals are formed without relying on capture techniques. We demonstrate our approach by developing assays for three classes of analytes--an ion, an enzyme, and a small molecule--using iron (III), acetylcholinesterase, and lactate, respectively. Additionally, we show these devices have the potential to support multiplexed assays by generating multiple lines in a common readout zone. These results highlight the ability of this new paper-based device architecture to aid the interpretation of assays that create soluble products by using flow to constrain those colorimetric products in a familiar, line-format output.
results.output_text: Accurate and rapid diagnoses rely heavily on interpreting result data from point-of-care devices, and lateral flow tests (LFTs) have been designed to simplify this user experience. Despite this, microfluidic paper-based analytical devices (μPADs) have failed to gain significant traction outside of academic laboratories due to their inconsistent shape and color signal output, leading to user-led misinterpretation of results. Here, we introduce a novel class of μPADs that produce colorimetric signals via converging liquid fronts, allowing for the controllable creation of lines to aid assay interpretation without relying on the traditional methods of capture. We demonstrate this approach using assays for three classes of analytes: ion, enzyme, and small molecule, with iron (III), acetylcholinesterase, and lactate, respectively. Furthermore, this new device architecture has the potential to support multiplexed assays, as the line-format output is easy to interpret for users. This innovative approach highlights the potential of paper-based devices to facilitate more accurate and straightforward diagnostic efforts, especially outside of academic surroundings.

results.input_text: Lateral flow test (LFT) strips have achieved widespread success in performing diagnostic tests at the point of care (POC) because their common architecture supports the development of a variety of immunoassay formats, utilizes scalable manufacturing processes to facilitate production and dissemination, and enables the interpretation of assay results by visual inspection. Nonetheless, the lateral flow device architecture largely limits testing to analytes that can be captured by immobilized molecular recognition agents (e.g., antibodies[1] or nucleic acids[2]) and testing is predominantly qualitative (i.e., presence or absence of a test line), both of which inherently restrict how broadly LFTs can be applied as a platform for POC measurements[3, 4]. As an alternative to LFTs, paper-based microfluidic devices or microfluidic paper analytical devices (\(\upmu\)PAD) have drawn appeal due to their potential to support a broader test menu than LFTs (e.g., cell counts, nucleic acid amplification, immunoassay)[5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10], compatibility with a wide range of assay readout methods (e.g., colorimetric, fluorescent, electrochemical, chemiluminescent)[11, 12, 13, 14, 15], ability to support device complexity (e.g., evaporative concentration, origami or "pop-up" assemblies, and fluid control valves)[5, 16, 17, 18] and utilize creative options for generating a user interface (e.g., wicking distance, timed readout, zones filled, and text appearance)[19, 20, 21, 22, 23].
results.output_text: Lateral flow test (LFT) strips have achieved widespread success in carrying out diagnostic tests at the point of care (POC) due to their versatile architecture, which supports various immunoassay formats, utilizes scalable manufacturing processes for mass production, and enables visual interpretation of results through simple observation. However, the lateral flow device structure restricts the breadth of its applicability as the commonly used assay method is qualitative, and the recognition agents used are limited to antibodies or nucleic acids. In contrast, paper-based microfluidic devices, or microfluidic paper analytical devices (μPAD), offer a broader test menu, such as cell counting and nucleic acid amplification, and are compatible with multiple readout methods, including colorimetric, fluorescent, electrochemical, and chemiluminescent. Additionally, these devices can support device complexity and offer creative options to generate a user interface, including adjusting wicking distance and timed readout. These features make μPADs a promising alternative to LFTs for comprehensive and advanced diagnostic testing at the POC.

results.input_text: The first paper-based microfluidic device, and similarly many subsequent prototypes, demonstrated the detection of analytes (e.g., glucose and albumin) using chemistries that formed soluble colorimetric reaction products within the void volume of patterned paper zones[12]. However, unlike litmus paper or urine dipstick tests, colorimetric products in \(\upmu\)PADs can have a non-uniform distribution within the test zone, which is caused either by unoptimized storage conditions (e.g., "coffee-ring effect" from dried reagents) or issues with balancing product diffusion or net fluid flow (i.e., by wicking)[24, 25, 26]. Heterogeneous signals in test zones, regardless of whether devices are designed to be operated in two- or three-dimensional configurations, can result in interpretation errors, particularly when printed read guides are presented with colors that are uniform in hue and spatial position[27].
results.output_text:
The first microfluidic device utilizing paper as a substrate, and subsequent iterations, demonstrated chemical detection of analytes, including glucose and albumin, via colorimetric reactions producing soluble products within specially designed paper zones. This approach differs from traditional methods involving litmus paper or urine dipsticks, as the colorimetric product's distribution within the test zone may be heterogeneous due to unoptimized storage conditions or balancing net fluid flow. This distribution can lead to measurement errors, particularly when read guides are presented in a uniform hue and spatial position. Two- or three-dimensional configurations may also be affected by this heterogeneous signal. 

In simpler terms, while microfluidic devices on paper can detect specific substances through color changes, the distribution of that color may not always be uniform, which can result in errors in interpretation. This is in contrast to traditional test methods, such as litmus paper or dipsticks, where the results are always consistent regardless of the color or position on the screen. This heterogeneity is primarily caused by issues with storage or fluid flow, but can also lead to errors when presenting test results using read guides that have a consistent hue and spatial layout.

results.input_text: A variety of strategies have been developed to address challenges related to the position and distribution of colorimetric signals in patterned paper zones. For assay formats that require molecular recognition, incorporation of nylon[10] or nitrocellulose[28] membranes into device designs can support reagent immobilization by physisorption and capture of analytes under continuous flow. Alternatively, the surfaces of cellulosic paper fibers can be functionalized chemically[29, 30, 31] or biochemically (e.g., via engineered proteins)[32, 33] to support the immobilization of reagents.[34, 35] Detection reagents can also be crosslinked throughout the open pore structure of a paper substrate to create an immobilized network of materials that would otherwise diffuse throughout the paper architecture.[36, 37] While these approaches provide assay developers with a variety of device design options, they each require target analytes to be captured or reagent-specific functionalization strategies to restrict the formation of a colorimetric signal to a defined location.
results.output_text: In order to address difficulties related to the arrangement and distribution of colorimetric signals in patterned paper zones, various strategies have been developed. For assay formats that require molecular recognition, nylon or nitrocellulose membranes can be employed to support reagent immobilization via physisorption, as well as capture of analytes in continuous flow. Additionally, chemically or biochemically functionalized cellulosic paper fibers can likewise support the immobilization of reagents. Alternatively, crosslinking of detection reagents within the open pore structure of paper can result in an immobilized network of materials that helps to preserve the colorimetric signal at a defined location. While these techniques offer assay developers many device design options, target analytes must still be captured or reagent-specific functionalization methods implemented in order to effectively minimize colorimetric signal creation at unwanted or unspecified locations.

results.input_text: To generate spatially-controlled, colorimetric signals without the requirements for molecular recognition or reagent immobilization, we developed a new class of paper-based microfluidic devices that form and confine colorimetric signals to the interfaces of converging liquid fronts (Figure 1A). The fluidic network patterned into the device splits a single sample inlet into separate and ultimately opposing channels. Analytes can undergo partial reactions with unique reagents stored in each channel. The products of these partial reactions are directed towards a common test zone. Others have shown paper devices designed for the sequential, timed delivery of reagents from multiple channels that are directed towards a test zone.[38, 39] In these devices, flow is continuous as long as sufficient volume is available to saturate the paper. Because paper-based devices are inherently self-metering,[5] if a single channel is split and recombined, net fluid flow stops when the advancing fluid fronts meet. At this interface between fronts, where reactions between previously separated reagents are now possible and controlled by diffusion, assay products can be isolated without affinity-based capture and lead to the formation of colorimetric signals that are confined to the contour of the interface. Using this device design strategy, we demonstrate the detection of multiple classes of analytes--ions, small molecules, and enzymes--by producing line-format signals like those provided by LFTs but resulting from soluble reaction products. We demonstrate our approach by developing assays for iron (III), acetylcholinesteraseiesterase, and lactate. Additionally, we demonstrate the scalability of this method by increasing the number of fluid fronts that converge in a common detection zone to create multiplexed assays: two converging channels create one interface (i.e., singleplex) while three or four converging channels create three or four interfaces, respectively (i.e., multiplex). We demonstrate the ability to create multiple lines in common zone by combining test and control assays for both iron (III) and acetylcholinesteraseiesterase. Overall, these devices provide a new method of generating user-friendly signal formats for analytes that are currently incompatible with molecular recognition-style assay architectures.
results.output_text: In pursuit of spatially-controlled and user-friendly signal formats for a diverse array of analytes, a new class of paper-based microfluidic devices has been developed (Figure 1A). This class of device is constructed to separate a single sample inlet into opposing unique channels, enabling partial reactions with unique reagents. The products of these partial reactions converge and meet at a common test zone, confining colorimetric signals to the interface between the advancing reagent fronts. This device design strategy differs from prior paper devices, which deliver reagents sequentially from multiple channels. Unlike these devices, which rely on continuous fluid flow, our design utilizes the self-metering properties of paper-based devices to stop net fluid flow when the advancing liquid fronts meet at an interface, leading to the formation of line-format signals in a common test zone that result from soluble reaction products. This new method is demonstrated through the development of assays for iron (III), acetylcholinesteraseinesterase, and lactate. results.input_text: The properties and quantities of reagents stored within paper layers determine rehydration times and the rates at which they wick through the device and toward the ultimate detection zone [39, 40]. For assays that require reagents with different chemical properties (e.g., solubility, rehydration rate, or interactions with the surrounding paper matrix) to be stored on opposite sides of the device, channel lengths may be adjusted to provide timed convergence of liquid fronts at the desired location [11, 41]. This approach is shown in Figure S1A, in which an interface formed between two solutions of colored dyes was shifted from the center of the device detection zone using an asymmetrical channel geometry. Additionally, the position of the formed interface is dependent on the geometries of patterned paper layer features and proper layer alignment [42, 43]. We developed a layer alignment pin tool and protocol to position device features reproducibly and ensure the interface position is only dependent on synchronized delivery of fluid fronts to the detection zone (Figure S2). This approach consistently provides interfaces at the center of device detection zones (Figure S1B). In the assays described below, a symmetrical channel design reproducibly afforded interfaces in the center of the test zone.
results.output_text: Liquid wicking and convergence rates within paper microfluidic devices are regulated by the properties and quantities of stored reagents, which affect their rehydration times and eventual propagation toward the detection zone. For instances where assays require reagents with distinct chemical characteristics to be stored on opposite sides of the device, channel lengths can be adjusted to ensure timely, converging liquid fronts at a designated area. This approach is exemplified by shifting the interface that forms between two colored dyes from the detection zone center by tailoring channel geometries (Figure S1A). By aligning paper layer features and proper layer alignment, utilizing a layer alignment pin tool and protocol, the position of the formed interface is only dependent on the synchronized delivery of fluid fronts at the detection zone, leading to consistent, centralized interface formation (Figure S1B). In the assays below, a symmetrical channel design was applied to obtain reproducible interface formation at the detection zone center.

results.input_text: While evaluating the reproducibility of signal formation in these three-dimensional devices, we noticed that the background color intensity of the detection zones was influenced by the wax pattern from the preceding layer (reagent storage) now being visualized through the wet, semi-transparent zone. In other three-dimensional paper-based device designs [10], output zones are typically backed by patterned paper channels, which are white in color to provide color contrast. In these interface-forming devices, however, detection zones are not in direct, vertical fluidic connection with patterned features on the previous layer. To enhance the contrast between colorimetric signal at liquid interfaces and the surrounding paper matrix, we altered our device design to include a patterned paper zone in the center of the reagent storage layer (Table S1) that is separate from the fluidic pathway of the assay and stays dry.
results.output_text: While examining the ability to reproduce signals in these three-dimensional devices, we discovered that the intensity of color in detection zones was impacted by the wax pattern left over from the previous layer that is currently being visualized via a semi-transparent and wet zone. To improve visibility of colorimetric signals at interfaces, we altered our design in certain three-dimensional paper-based devices [10] by introducing a separate dry, patterned paper zone situated in the center of the reagent storage layer (refer to Table S1). Unlike other designs, the detection zones in our devices do not have direct, vertical fluidic connectivity with patterned features on the previous layer, which are ordinarily designed to provide color contrast. By including a separate, dry zone, we aim to enhance the contrast between signals produced by the assay and the background paper matrix.

results.input_text: These paper devices perform assays through multistep or partial-step chemical reactions that are carried out in opposing channels but from a single sample input. The resultant colorimetric signal only forms when the advancing liquid fronts converge, and reagents and intermediate products can react by diffusing across the formed interface. In the single-analyte detection format, reagents are stored within the device such that one channel contains analyte-specific reagents, and the other channel contains a product-specific indicator. Upon introduction of the sample, a partial reaction occurs in the channel containing analyte-specific reagents. As the two liquid fronts converge, the assay is completed by reaction between the formed product and the product-specific indicator. Thus, a colorimetric interfacial signal develops in the readout zone and the signal is confined in the interface contour due to reaction specificity and timed transport of solutions.

results.input_text: We performed signal analysis using ImageJ.[44] To analyze signal intensity at the interface, we either (i) used the "Plot Profile" tool and analyzed the pixel intensity across the circular signal readout region or (ii) defined the interfacial signal using the "Rectangle" tool and then performed "RGB Measure" analysis using the available plugin. The time required to generate visible signals can vary based on the grade of paper used to fabricate the device (Table S2). We used Whatman 4 for all layers of our paper-based device and observed that signal formation starts at approximately 2 minutes. Products accumulate over time and cause an increase in signal intensity, until saturating at approximately 7 minutes after the sample was added (Figure 2A). Additionally, the gradual increase in signal intensity causes nearly linear broadening of the width of the formed interface over time, which eventually compromises signal intensity. Therefore, we determined the ideal signal read time is between 7-10 minutes, with the cut off time for signal interpretation to be 20 minutes. Prior to the cut off time, the signal intensity is at a maximum value and can be used for qualitative detection, which we demonstrate with Fe(III) ions (Figure 2B). Signal intensities at 2 minutes and 100 minutes resulted in similar intensity values (data not shown). Longer times lead to diminishing signal intensity due to diffusion of product.

Between 7-10 minutes, the signal intensity is at a maximum value and can be utilized for qualitative detection, as demonstrated with Fe(III) ions (Figure 2B). results.input_text: For the representative ion assay, we selected Fe(III). Iron homeostasis is vital to multiple biological processes (e.g., oxygen transport and short-term oxygen storage) and the concentration of iron can be used as a diagnostic marker for anemia.[45] We chose Fe(III) as a model analyte to highlight two key functions of our device: (i) the separation of reduction and chelation reactions and (ii) the spatial confinement of low molecular weight products. To detect Fe(III), we stored ascorbic acid (a reducing agent) and 3-(2-pyridyl)-5,6-diphenyl-1,2,4-triazine-p,p'-disulfonic acid (Ferrozine; a colorimetric indicator of Fe(II))[46] in opposite channels of the reagent storage layer (Figure 3A). When a sample is added to the device, it is split uniformly intoeach channel where it rehydrates and can react with these stored reagents. If Fe(III) is present in the sample, it will be reduced to Fe(II) in the channel containing ascorbic acid, while no reactions will occur in the channel containing Ferrozine. When the two wicking fronts converge at the detection zone on the bottom layer of the device, reduced Fe(II) is chelated by Ferrozine and forms a purple signal at the formed interface (Figure 3B, Figure S4).

results.input_text: In some experiments, we observed a noticeable background signal in the channel containing Ferrozine that scaled with the concentration of added Fe(III) (Figure S5). The presence of this background color could negatively impact the performance of the Fe(III) assay (i.e., reduced specificity and increased limit of detection). This color, a reaction product with Ferrozine, could be caused by Fe(II) impurities in either the Fe(III) sample or the paper[47]. We minimized the background signal by incorporating ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) in the Ferrozine side of the sample distribution layer[48]. We tested both the effect of different EDTA and Ferrozine concentrations on the signal to background ratio (Table S3, Table S4). As the concentration of Ferrozine increased, the intensities of both the signal formed at the readout zone and the background increased. The increase in background intensity did not negatively impact the signal to background ratio, which increased proportionally with the concentration of Ferrozine. However, the increase in signal to background ratio in the presence of EDTA was higher than that without using EDTA, which further suggests that the incorporation of EDTA provided superior results (Table S3, Table S4).
results.output_text: In certain experiments, we identified a distinguishable background signal in the channel housing Ferrozine that grew commensurate with the added concentration of iron(III) (see Figure S5). The presence of the aforementioned background color could have negative consequences for the efficacy of the iron(III) quantification (i.e., reduced specificity and increased lower limit of detection). This color reaction could manifest due to an impurity of iron(II) in either the iron(III) sample or the medium (paper). To reduce this background signal we incorporated ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) to the sample distribution layer[48]. By testing different concentrations of Ferrozine and EDTA (see Tables S3 and S4), we observed that as Ferrozine concentrations increased, the intensity of both the readout zone signal and background increased. However, the enhancement in the signal to background ratio did not decrease by increasing the background. With the use of EDTA, the signal to background ratio saw a higher increase, which reinforces the claim that EDTA's incorporation offers superior results.

results.input_text: The addition of samples containing Fe(III) resulted in interfaces with colors whose intensities correlated linearly with concentration between 5.8-13.0 mM and had an LOD of 2.9 mM (Figure 3C). We chose this range of concentrations as it corresponds to the biologically relevant concentration of total iron that could be liberated from hemoglobin[49]. While quantitative analysis is useful to characterize assay performance as changes are made to reagent conditions for device design, ultimately, we envision the application of this approach to be similar to how LFTsoperate--using the formation (or absence) of a line as a qualitative indicator of the presence (or absence) of an analyte (Figure 3D).
results.output_text: At Fe(III) sample concentrations between 5.8 and 13.0 mM, our assay produced interface colors whose intensity was directly proportional to the concentration, as shown in Figure 3C. This concentration range is of particular interest as it encompasses the biologically relevant concentration of iron that could be released from hemoglobin[49]. Quantitative analysis provides an effective means for characterizing assay performance upon reagent condition modification for device design; however, for practical application, our system is intended to function in a similar manner to LFTs, serving as a qualitative indicator of analyte presence or absence based on the visual observation of line formation.

results.input_text: For the representative enzyme assay, we selected AChE. AChE hydrolyzes the neurotransmitter acetylcholine into choline and acetic acid to terminate neurotransmission at the cholinergic synapse. Inhibition of AChE by organophosphates, heavy metals, or chemical warfare agents can block acetylcholine transmission and lead to organ failure and death [50]. We chose AChE as a model analyte to evaluate how interfaces were formed when reactions were governed by two time-dependent processes: (i) the activity of the enzyme (i.e., the analyte) and (ii) diffusion and mixing of reactants across the interface. To detect AChE, we stored acetylcholine chloride and 5,5'-dithiobis(2-nitrobenzoic acid) (DTNB, Ellman's reagent) on opposite sides of the reagent storage layer (Figure S6). When AChE is present in the added sample, it reacts with acetylcholine to produce acetic acid and thiocholine (Figure 4A). At the interface, the unmasked sulfhydryl group on the thiocholine interacts with DTNB to generate 2-nitro-5-thiobenzoic acid and form a yellow signal that we could quantify with image analysis. As expected for an enzymatic assay, the signal intensities saturated over time. Similar to the Fe(III) assay, signal from AChE assay took approximately two minutes to start forming and increased in width and intensity over time. To ensure color saturation, we used the scans taken 10 minutes after sample addition to analyze the signal intensity formed at the interface. We performed nonlinear regression of the data using a saturation growth model for concentrations of AChE ranging from 2-30 U/mL (Figure 4B). From the fit, we determined that there was a nearly linear relationship between the concentration of AChE and measured signal between 2-10 U/mL, and signals at higher concentrations were saturated and could be detected but not quantified. While the physiological range of AChE in plasma is greater than 8 U/mL [51], exposure to dangerous chemical agents (e.g., organophosphates) results in a reduction of AChE activity into the linear range of this assay. While it can be hard to detect yellow lines on white backgrounds with the naked eye, especially at lower analyte concentrations, this AChE assay remains useful to provide a visual reference for qualitative detection (i.e., "yes or no" presence of analyte). Given the versatility of our device design, it is possible to substitute assay reagents (i.e., other colorimetric substrates)[50] for AChE to enhance signal contrast.

results.input_text: For the representative small molecule assay, we selected lactate. Lactate is an intermediate in the metabolic anerobic carbohydrate pathway whose concentration in sweat changes with exercise. While exercising, undesired lactate accumulation in the active muscle can manifest as fatigue, soreness, and pain[52]. Also, sweat lactate can provide information about insufficient oxidative metabolism and pressure ischemia[53]. We chose lactate as a model analyte to demonstrate how the device can accommodate multistep reactions. To detect lactate, we stored (i) nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and (ii) 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolzolium bromide (MTT) on opposite sides of the second layer of the device (Figure 5A). Then on the third layer, we again stored NAD+/LDH below the first treated layer and phenazine methosulfate (PMS) below MTT (Figure S7). When a sample containing lactate is introduced and split by the sample distribution layer, the following reactions occur: (i) LDH converts lactate to pyruvate and (ii) transfers the liberated hydride ion to the co-stored NAD+ to produce NADH. In the other channel, both MTT and PMS are simply rehydrated. When the split sample converges at the interface, PMS mediates an electron transfer from NADH to reduce MTT and produce a purple-colored formazan product.

results.input_text: In Figure 1, we demonstrated that it was possible to design a device such that multiple, independent channels (i.e., 3-4) could converge in a common zone to create multiple interfaces. While this preliminary experiment was performed with dyes stored in the device and rehydrated only with water, the results showed several useful features that were analogous to the singleplex format: (i) equal channel lengths and design symmetry could control the position of interfaces in a common zone, (ii) mixing only occurs across interfaces formed from advancing fronts, and (iii) net flow stops when the read zone is filled to allow reactions to be confined only to formed interfaces. As a result, we evaluated the potential to create multiplexed assays using the interface device design by combining two of the aforementioned singleplex assays.
results.output_text: In Figure 1, we presented proof that it is feasible to construct a device capable of simultaneously facilitating multiple, independent channels (approximately three to four). In contrast to traditional methods, our initial experiment employed dyes stored within the device, which were then rehydrated using water as the only fluid source. Our preliminary results provided multiple favorable attributes. To begin, the identical lengths and design symmetry of the channels ensured that interfaces converged in a shared zone. Furthermore, the mixing process occurred exclusively across interfaces created by advancing fronts. Lastly, by halting net flow when the reading zone is occupied, the process enables a confined reaction to occur only within the formed interfaces. In light of these features, we explored the possibility of devising a multiplex assay by integrating two singleplex assays with this interface device design.

results.input_text: Taking inspiration from a standard LFT, which comprises a single test line and single control line, we aimed to demonstrate the ability of our devices to support multiple test and control lines in the same read zone. We chose to develop an assay for Fe(lll) and AChE, which would produce four interfacial signals: one test line and one control line for each respective analyte.
results.output_text: This study aims to demonstrate the versatility of our product by constructing a multiplexed lateral flow test (LFT) device. The device consists of multiple test lines and control lines in a single read zone, deviating from the standard LFT that only comprises a single test line and single control line. The LFT device presented in this article will detect two specific analytes, Fe(III) and acetylcholinesterase (AChE), through four interfacial signals, two test lines and two control lines for each respective analyte.

One major difference from the singleplex assays is that control interfaces require the storage and eventual introduction of the partial reaction products formed in the test interfaces--namely, ferrous iron (FeCl\({}_{2}\)) and a free thiol (cysteine)--to react with stored indicators. After all four channels wick through to the final layer, the four resulting liquid fronts converge at the detection zone and form four interfacial signals. At the detection zone, a yellow interface formed at position 1 indicates the presence of AChE, a yellow interface formed at position 2 indicates the corresponding control line for AChE, a purple interface formed at position 3 indicates the presence of control line for Fe(III), and finally, a purple interface formed at position 4 indicates the presence of Fe(III). results.output_text: The figure illustrated in S8 portrays the procedures for introducing the test reagents into appropriate spatial locations (in layers and channels) distinct from those used in singleplex assays. In contrast to the previous method, the control interfaces are designed to store and eventually introduce the partial reaction products formed in the test interfaces, namely ferrous iron (FeCl\({}_{2}\)) and a free thiol (cysteine), to their respective stored indicators. A purple interface at position 3 denotes the presence of control line for Fe(III), while purple coloration at position 4 represents Fe(III) detection. results.input_text: In this manuscript, we report a new class of paper-based microfluidic devices that uses converging liquid fronts to constrain the location where assay chemistries are performed within test zones. Like the ubiquitous lateral flow test, which serve as an inspiration for the readout format of these devices, the shape of the colorimetric assay product is a line. We made this design decision to facilitate how assay results are interpreted[55], either qualitatively or quantitively. Unlike lateral flow tests, however, these paper devices do not rely on molecular recognition or affinity capture to immobilize analytes of interest or colorimetric reagents. Instead, by converging and halting two opposing wicking fronts, the location of soluble reaction products can be defined. While we show the potential for this device format to support colorimetric assays for Fe(III), acetylcholinesterasecholinesterase, and lactate, we believe that similar applications are possible for other analytes represented by these classes (i.e., ions, enzymes, and small molecules).
results.output_text: We present a novel class of paper-based microfluidic devices that utilize converging liquid fronts to restrict the location of chemical reactions within test zones. Similar to lateral flow tests, which served as a model for the readout format of these devices, the hue indicative of a reaction is a line. A deliberate design choice was made to aid the interpretation of assay results, either qualitatively or quantitatively. This divergence from lateral flow tests is essential, as these paper devices don't rely on molecular recognition or affinity capture to confine a sample of interest or colored reagents. Rather, the device format converges and halts two opposing wicking fronts, enabling a specified location of soluble reaction products. The benefits of this device format are evident in various assay types, including colorimetric measurements for Fe(III), acetylcholinesterasecholinesterase, and lactate. These classes, including ions, enzymes, and small molecules, are potentially suited for this device format.

results.input_text: In addition to singleplex assays for each of these analytes, we further demonstrate that multiplexed assays--where multiple fluid fronts carrying distinct reaction products and/orindicators--can be supported by this approach to form interfaces in paper test zones. Unlike in singleplex assays, where efforts to optimize assay conditions and formulate reagents for storage within the device have relatively limited variables, the creation of multiplexed assays requires deliberate attention to reagent compatibility and cross-reactivity to limit false positives and negatives. Even so, the opportunity to integrate positive controls, which are frequently missing from assays developed for paper-based microfluidic devices, would address a major requirement for point-of-care tests. Beyond their use as procedural controls, we anticipate that the intensities of these lines may have the potential to be used as visual comparators to estimate the concentration of the analyte in the sample. In total, the unique design of these devices has the potential to simplify the user experience and interpretation of critical results at the point-of-use, while broadening the analytical capabilities and ultimate utility of paper-based microfluidic sensors.
results.output_text: Furthermore, our research demonstrates that multiplexed assays, which involve creating multiple fluid fronts carrying diverse reaction products, can be supported using this method for forming interfaces in paper test zones. These assays present complex challenges compared to their singleplex counterparts, including the need for optimized assay conditions and compatible reagents to avoid false positives and negatives. results.input_text: The benefits of oxalic acid modulation are not limited to MIL-53, as they were also observed for its analogues with OH-, CH\({}_{3}\)O-, Br-, and NO\({}_{2}\)-functionalised linkers. These MOFs were synthesized using 0.5, 1, and 1.5 oxalic acid:Al ratios to study how the amount of modulator affects the crystallinity of the products. In all the studied systems, oxalic acid leads to an increased crystal size with respect to the unmodulated synthesis (Figure 2, Figures S9-S23). Interestingly, a higher modulator-to-Al ratio does not always result in improved crystallinity. Indeed, in the cases of OH- and CH\({}_{3}\)O-MIL-53, an excessive amount of modulator leads to the stabilisation of a specific size or the absence of solid products, respectively. This behaviour can be attributed to the electron-donor character of OH and CH\({}_{3}\)O groups[45], which lowers the acidity of terephthalatic acid by destabilising its conjugated base[46]. Additionally, the pH decrease due to the MOF synthesis and to the formation of aluminium oxalate complexes further disfavours the deprotonation of the linkers, thus diminishing their reactivity. Our results show that the combination of these effects can allow for the tuning of the product's size distribution, in addition to its crystallinity. However, to achieve such control several aspects should be considered, in particular the modulator concentration, the species formed during the synthesis, and the chemical properties of the linker. Therefore, the adequate conditions to stabilize a specific size must be optimised for every system.

results.input_text: Having confirmed the effectiveness of oxalic acid in the synthesis of functionalised MIL-53, we extended its use to additional AI-MOFs with varying linker molecules and IBUs, namely CAU-10[47], MIL-69[48], and AI(OH)ndc[49] (ndc = 1,4-nophtalenedactorabytate). These three materials were obtained as nanocrystalline powders by conventional synthesis, whereas the introduction of oxalic acid modulation afforded crystals up to 5 \(\upmu\)m for CAU-10, 20 \(\upmu\)m for MIL-69, and 70 \(\upmu\)m for AI(OH)ndc (Figure 2, Figures S24-S35). Although the performance of the modulator depends strongly on the type of material, the oxalic acid modulation method proved its validity on these systems despite their different structure and assembly. Even in the case of the notably different linker geometry and IBU structure of CAU-10, the kinetic control introduced by oxalic acid coordination to the metals improves the crystallinity while limiting the occurrence of crystal twinning and the formation of intergrown domains.

The original synthesis method yielded nanocrystalline powders; however, introducing the oxalic acid modulation approach produced crystals sized up to 5 µm, 20 µm, and 70 µm, respectively (see Figure 2 and Figures S24-S35). Despite CAU-10's inherently different linker geometry and IBU structure compared to MIL-69 and AI(OH)ndc, the use of oxalic acid modulation proved the method's validity for these systems as well. This technique offers kinetic control to the metals, promoting improved crystallinity and limiting undesirable crystal twinning and the formation of intergrown domains.

results.input_text: In conclusion, the use of oxalic acid as synthesis modulator for various AI-MOFs affords products with an unprecedented crystallinity without affecting the materials' structure and composition. Although the outcome of this approach is highly dependent on the framework's structure as well as on the synthetic conditions, its efficacy has been confirmed for all the examined systems regardless of linker functionalisation or type of material. We attribute this remarkable versatility to oxalic acid's synergistic action in both binding the metals and protonating the linkers, thus introducing a substantial control over the MOF nucleation and regulating the crystal growth. Furthermore, we described how the strong differences between its characteristic five-membered ring chelation and the linker's coordination mode in the studied materials allow the modulating function without causing substitutional defects. These advantages do not apply in the case of modulators whose coordination capabilities are compatible with those found in the IBUs, such as fluoride or monocarboxylate species. Further applications of oxalic acid modulation to other AI-MOFs, as well as frameworks based on different metals, will be crucial to assess more thoroughly its validity and highlight additional MOF-specific particularities and advantages associated with its use.
results.output_text: In summary, the incorporation of oxalic acid as a modifying agent in the synthesis of various AI-MOFs results in a crystalline final product without altering the structure or composition of the materials. This approach is highly effective for all examined systems, regardless of linker functionalization or material type, and is attributed to oxalic acid's binding ability for metals and its role in regulating crystal growth through protonation of linkers. Crucially, the chelation properties of oxalic acid versus the coordination capabilities of the linkers do not lead to structural substitutions, and therefore offer a unique advantage over other modulators such as fluoride or monocarboxylate species. As we continue to explore the application of oxalic acid modulation to other AI-MOFs and frameworks based on different metals, we hope to fully appreciate the versatility and potential benefits associated with this synthesis approach.

results.input_text:
Quantum coherence of S = \(
icefrac{{1}}{{2}}\) transition metal-based quantum bits (qubits) is strongly influenced by the magnitude of spin-phonon coupling. While this coupling is recognized as deriving from dynamic distortions about the first coordination sphere of the metal, a general model for understanding and quantifying ligand field contributions has not been established. Here we derive a general ligand field theory model to describe and quantify the nature of spin-phonon coupling terms in S = \(
icefrac{{1}}{{2}}\) transition metal complexes. We show that the coupling term for a given vibrational mode is governed by: 1) the magnitude of the metal-based spin-orbit coupling constant, 2) the magnitude and gradient in the ligand field excited state energy, and 3) dynamic relativistic nephelauxetic contributions reflecting the magnitude and gradient in the covalency of the ligand-metal bonds. From an extensive series of density functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TDDFT) calculations calibrated to a range of experimental data, spin-phonon coupling terms describing minimalistic \(D_{\mu\mu}/D_{2d}\) [CuCl\({}_{4}\)]\({}^{2}\)- and \(C_{
u
u}\) [VOCl\({}_{4}\)]\({}^{2}\)- complexes translate to and correlate with experimental quantum coherence properties observed for Cu(II)- and V(IV)-based molecular qubits with different ligand sets, geometries, and coordination numbers. While providing a fundamental framework and means to benchmark current qubits, the model and methodology described herein can be used to screen any S = \(
icefrac{{1}}{{2}}\) molecular qubit candidate and guide the discovery of room temperature coherent materials for quantum information processing.
results.output_text: The strength of quantum coherence in S = \(\nicefrac{1}{2}\) transition metal-based quantum bits (qubits) can be significantly impacted by the magnitude of spin-phonon coupling. Despite its critical role, a comprehensive model for understanding this coupling and quantifying ligand field contributions has not been established. In this study, we developed a theory-based framework to determine the coupling terms for vibrational modes. This model is influenced by three factors: magnitudes of metal-based spin-orbit coupling constant, variation in ligand field excited state energy, and dynamic relativistic nephelauxetic contributions stemming from the magnitude and gradient of ligand-metal covalency. By conducting DFT and TDDFT calculations, we were able to correlate theoretical spin-phonon coupling terms with observed coherent properties in Cu(II) and V(IV) molecular qubits with varying ligand sets, geometries, and coordination numbers. This model can serve as a benchmark for current qubits and as a tool to screen future candidates, ultimately guiding the discovery of room temperature coherent materials for quantum information processing.

results.input_text: The coupling of electron spin to phonons/vibrations plays important roles in the dynamical properties of transition metal complexes and materials. For example, spin-phonon coupling plays a major role in the photophysical and photochemical properties of transition metal complexes, including ultrafast spin state switching and intersystem crossing, wherein it provides a strong influence on nonequilibrium dynamics.[1, 2, 3, 4, 5] It is also a major factor in the magnetization dynamics of single molecule magnets[6, 7, 8, 9] and coherent materials for quantum information science.[10, 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16] Beyond molecular systems, spin-phonon coupling also plays important roles in extended solids and condensed matter (e.g., transition metal oxides) by giving rise to emergent phenomena such as colossal magnetoresistance and high \(T_{C}\) superconductivity,[17, 18, 19, 20, 21, 22] including vibrational or optical control of these properties.[23, 24, 25, 26] Thus, fundamental studies of spin-phonon coupling can provide insights into a variety of research areas, and there are fascinating intersections between the nature of spin-phonon coupling in molecular systems (e.g., mononuclear, binuclear, and multinuclear transition metal complexes) and extended solids to be explored.
results.output_text: The intimate connection between electron spin and vibrations/phonons is crucial to both the dynamical properties of transition metal complexes and materials and the broader field of quantum information science. For example, in transition metal complexes, spin-phonon coupling affects the ultrafast spin state switching and intersystem crossing, which can influence non-equilibrium dynamics, and is also essential to the magnetization dynamics of single molecule magnets. In condensed materials such as transition metal oxides, spin-phonon coupling gives rise to emergent phenomena such as colossal magnetoresistance and high superconductivity temperatures. These insights extend beyond molecular systems, and fundamental studies of spin-phonon coupling can offer valuable insights into not only the aforementioned research areas, but also a variety of research fields. Furthermore, intriguing intersections between spin-phonon coupling in transition metal complexes and extended solids await exploration.

results.input_text: Recent research has focused on the use of \(\mathrm{S=\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}\) transition metal complexes as quantum bits (qubits), as the magnetic field split electron spin sublevels (\(\mathrm{M_{s}=\pm\ 1/2}\)) provide a two-level system in which a coherent superposition state can be formed. This coherent superposition state, often initiated with a well-defined microwave pulse sequence in an electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrometer (\(\sim\)9 or 35 GHz for X- or Q-band, respectively), can be leveraged to satisfy DiVincenzo's criteria for the physical implementation of a quantum computer.[27] However, the lifetime of this state must be significantly longer than the gate operation time, and a significant challenge in the domain of molecular qubits is to understand the principles controlling coherence lifetimes. This understanding can then be leveraged for the synthetic design of new transition metal complexes with long-lived coherent states.
results.output_text: Investigations in recent times have focused on the implementation of \(\mathrm{S=\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}}\) transition metal complexes for quantum computing, as these complexes have electron spin sublevels that can provide a two-level system when subjected to a magnetic field (\(\mathrm{M_{s}=\pm\ 1/2}\)). Such a system can be used to create a coherent superposition state, which is often initiated with a well-defined microwave pulse sequence in an electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectrometer (\(\sim\)9 or 35 GHz for X- or Q-band, respectively). These superposition states can satisfy the criteria for designing a quantum computer, as stated by DiVincenzo. However, the lifetime of these states must be longer than the gate operation time, which is a significant challenge in the domain of molecular qubits. A better understanding of the principles controlling coherence lifetimes can aid in the synthesis of new, transition metal complexes with longer-lived coherent states.

results.output_text: Many of the most efficient qubits with spin-state S = \(\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}\) share common structural frameworks: a square planar complex of copper(II) with four equivalent ligands, or a vanadyl-based structure featuring a triple bond between the vanadium(IV) center and a terminal oxide group. Ligand field theory (LFT) has provided expressions for understanding geometric and electronic structure contributions to the g-values of Cu(II) complexes [54]. Here this model is extended more generally to a dynamic regime, which allows for the direct understanding of spin-phonon coupling contributions to the g-values of \(\mathrm{S=
icefrac{{1}}{{2}}}\) transition metal complexes. Using the ORCA program [55, 56], the LFT expressions are further supported by a range of spectroscopically calibrated density functional theory (DFT) and time-dependent DFT (TDDFT) calculations on the well-studied \(D_{4h}\) and \(D_{2d}\) [CuCl\({}_{4}\)] [2- and \(C_{4v}\) [VOCI\({}_{4}\)] [57, 58]. The correlations between experiment and LFT, DFT, and TDDFT calculations have elucidated the key factors that contribute to the nature of spin-phonon coupling terms in \(\mathrm{S=
icefrac{{1}}{{2}}}\) transition metal complexes, thus providing a detailed orbital and bonding picture for the first time. The model presented here indicates spin-phonon coupling terms are governed by the magnitude of the metal-based spin-orbit coupling (SOC) constant, excited state mixing of orbital angular momentum into the ground state, and dynamic relativistic nephelaavetic contributions. The latter contribution is directly related to the covalencies of ligand-metal bonds and can modify the metal-based SOC constant from that of the free ion in a dynamic manner. Also, correlations between dynamic ground state orbital angular momentum and excited state coupling terms and their relations to spin-phonon coupling terms are drawn for the first time. Specific group theoretical correlations between high and lower symmetry point groups further provide a means to evaluate spin-phonon coupling terms across transition metal complexes and molecular qubits featuring different ligand sets, geometries, and coordination numbers. The model is in excellent agreement with a wide range of experimental quantum coherence properties of Cu(II)- and V(IV)-based molecular qubits and therefore provides a means to rapidly evaluate spin-phonon coupling terms in any \(\mathrm{S=
icefrac{{1}}{{2}}}\) transition metal complex, including new qubit candidates.

results.input_text: Transition metal complexes are being explored as qubits for quantum computing. In addition to significant hurdles related to the eventual quantum entanglement of molecular qubits, spin-phonon coupling in transition metal complexes often prohibits the observation of room temperature coherence properties. This has inspired resent research efforts to better understand the nature of spin-phonon coupling in transition metal complexes and how it might be tuned and controlled by variations in the ligand set and thus the ligand field environment.[13, 14, 15, 33, 44] As highlighted in the Introduction, spin-phonon couplings also play important roles in single molecule magnets and photophysics, and studies directed at fundamental understanding will have broad impact.

One crucial obstacle is spin-phonon coupling in these complexes, which frequently prevents achieving room temperature coherence. To address this issue, recent investigations are focusing on understanding the nature of spin-phonon coupling and how it might be controlled by modifications in the ligand set and consequent ligand field environment. These efforts aim to develop a better understanding of spin-phonon coupling, with significant implications in the study of single molecule magnets and photophysics. icefrac{{1}}{{2}}\) transition metal complexes. This suggests that, without considering thermal population, odd modes such as totally symmetric stretches will have a more substantial effect on spin-phonon coupling terms and decoherence compared to even modes, in which their value of relevance, \( rac{\partial^{2}g_{z}}{\partial q_{l}^{2}}\), only appears in the second order term of the Taylor expansion (equation 5). The fundamental behavior of these expressions were borne out by an extensive range of DFT and TD-DFT calculations on minimalistic S = \(
icefrac{{1}}{{2}}\) models, \(D_{4h}\)/\(D_{2d}\) [CuCl\({}_{4}\)]\({}^{2}\)- and \(C_{\mathcal{H}}\) [VOCl\({}_{4}\)]\({}^{2}\)-. Together, the results above provide a general description of the roles of transition metal geometric and electronic structure in spin-phonon coupling. For instance, the magnitudes of spin-phonon coupling terms are strongly influenced by excited state SOC of orbital angular momentum into the ground state and are predicted to be strongly influenced by the energy of the particular ligand field excited state mixing with the ground state (equations 6 and 7) (e.g., \({}^{2}\)B\({}_{2g}\) for a \({}^{2}\)B\({}_{1g}\) ground state in \(D_{4h}\) [CuCl\({}_{4}\)]\({}^{2}\)-). This excited state SOC contribution is governed by the ligand field geometry about the metal complex. For example, going from \(D_{4h}\) to \(D_{2d}\) [CuCl\({}_{4}\)]\({}^{2}\)- turns on additional mode coupling terms due to the enhancement of excited state coupling terms (Figure 4). Furthermore, the magnitude of spin-phonon coupling terms are strongly influenced by the covalency of ligand-metal bonds. This dynamic effect largely reflects a relativistic nephelauxetic effect, which effectively modulates the SOC constant of the metal from that of the free ion. In short, the more covalent the ligand-metal bond, the smaller the spin-phonon coupling terms become. Relatedly, a significant overall reduction in SOC constant can of course be achieved through the use of different transition metal complexes (e.g., V(IV) vs. Cu(II) vs. Cr(V)). As shown below, V(IV), which has a significantly lower SOC constant than Cu(II), can still maintain favorable spin-phonon coupling terms despite having significantly more ionic ligand-metal bonds than Cu(II) complexes. Complications can also arise from trying to quantify spin-phonon coupling terms in different ligand field environments, as the nature of the modes can change. However, this can be facilitated to some degree by leveraging specific group theoretical correlations as demonstrated here for \(D_{4h}\), \(D_{2d}\), and \(C_{\mathcal{H}}\) transition metal complexes. The spin-phonon analyses presented above for [CuCl\({}_{4}\)]\({}^{2}\)- and [VOCl\({}_{4}\)]\({}^{2}\)- are now extended to a range of S = \(
icefrac{{1}}{{2}}\) Cu(II) and V(IV) molecular qubit candidates.

results.input_text: The spin-phonon model presents a stark difference for vandyl vs. six coordinate V(IV) complexes. As shown in Sessoli et al.[13, 53], six coordinate V(IV) complexes do not exhibit long \(T_{I}\)s at elevated temperatures. Very recently, Albino et al.[13] pointed to the role of increased excited state SOC in six coordinate complexes relative to vandyl complexes. Furthermore, Fataftah et al.[33] compared six coordinate V(IV) complexes to Cu(II) complexes to suggest the role of increased covalency in elongating \(T_{I}\) relaxation lifetimes. Here we have extended our LFT model to the V(bdt)\({}_{3}\) and V(bds)\({}_{3}\) complexes studied by Fataftah et al.[33] (Table 6). Interestingly, as pointed out by Albino et al.[13] for other six coordinate V(IV) complexes, the V(bdt)\({}_{3}\) and V(bds)\({}_{3}\) complexes exhibit very low energy calculated ligand field transitions (7935 and 6785 cm-1, respectively). Furthermore, the totally symmetric stretches of these complexes were computed at 351.7 and 209.8 cm-1, respectively. These modes allow for a quantitative comparison between the linear spin-phonon coupling term of Cu(II) complexes on a A-1 scale. The linear coupling terms for V(bds)\({}_{6}\) in the g\({}_{\parallel}\) and g\({}_{\perp}\) regions are -0.420 and -0.357 g/A, respectively. For comparison, the linear coupling term of the totally symmetric \(a_{lg}\) parent mode of Cu(bdt)\({}_{2}\) is smaller (0.232 g/A). Also, the calculated vibrational frequency decreases and the linear coupling terms increase going from V(bdt)\({}_{3}\) to V(bds)\({}_{3}\). Thus, the longer spin-lattice relaxation time at higher temperatures for Cu(bdt)\({}_{2}\) vs. V(bdt)\({}_{3}\) is not due to differences in ligand-metal covalency, but rather stems from efficient excited state SOC as a result of the relatively low energy ligand field transition energies for V(bdt)\({}_{3}\). This is further supported by the observation of room temperature coherence in vandylcomplexes,[37] despite ionic ligand metal bonding. Together, these DFT/TDDFT calculations are consistent with the LFT model derived here and further highlight the importance of considering both excited state SOC and ligand-metal covalency when comparing different complexes with different metals and/or coordination environments.

results.input_text: As previously highlighted for \(D_{4h}/D_{2d}\) [CuCl\({}_{4}\)]\({}^{2}\)-, the planar \(D_{4h}\) Cu(II) structure represents a saddle point on the ground state potential energy surface that can only be stabilized in the presence of crystal packing forces.[57, 58] The formation of this structure in [CuCl\({}_{4}\)]\({}^{2}\)- was likened to the nematic/rack state in bioinorganic chemistry, where the protein architecture (inclusive of first and second sphere contributions, as well as long range H-bonding and electrostatics) can place a metal ion in a strained ligand field.[78, 79, 80, 81] This ligand field strain can generate unique properties. The entic/rack state and ligand field strain is therefore of relevance to molecular qubits. For example, Cu(II)-based complexes with the longest coherence times are square planar Cu(II) sites stabilized in diamagnetic lattices (e.g., Cu(mnt)\({}_{2}\)[50] and Cu(bdt)\({}_{2}\)[33]). The geometric dependence to \(T_{I}\) was also noted in an EPR study of a variety of Cu(II) complexes.[69] Here we have shown that the origin of this dependence for the square planar Cu(II) geometry derives from the significant minimization of excited state coupling terms, which reduces dynamic SOC of orbital angular momentum into the ground state (Figure 4).
results.output_text: In previous studies on [CuCl\({}_{4}\)]\({}^{2}\)-, the saddle point planar D\({}_{4h}\) Cu(II) structure has been identified as a form that can only be stabilized by crystal packing forces, as opposed to the ground state potential energy surface. This phenomenon has been likened to bioinorganic chemistry, where protein architecture can place metal ions in a strained ligand field, creating a nematic/rack state associated with unique properties. As Cu(II)-based complexes with the longest coherence times possess square planar Cu(II) sites stabilized in diamagnetic lattices, the geometric dependence to T\({}_{I}\) has been noted. In a recent EPR study, the origin of this dependence for the square planar Cu(II) geometry was discovered as the result of minimized excited state coupling terms, which reduce dynamic spin-orbit coupling of orbital angular momentum into the ground state, as illustrated in Figure 4.

results.input_text: In addition to crystal packing forces, variations in the ligand set can effectively control the deviation from planarity in Cu(II) complexes. This can be observed directly in the dependence of the electronic energy as a function of the \(b_{2u}\) parent mode (in \(D_{4h}\)) distortion. For instance, as noted above, distortion along this mode will decrease the energy for the square planar Cu(II) complexes studied here, which results in the \(b_{2u}\) mode being imaginary. However, this is not the case for CuPc. Thus, linking the four N-based ligands into the aromatic planar structure of the Pc ligand provides an entictic state that can oppose distortions along the \(b_{2u}\) parent mode. However, the drawback of the Pc ligand arises also from its N-based coordination, which gives rise to fairly ionic ligand-metal bonds and opposes the effects provided by the rigid and constrained ligand field (i.e., entic state).
results.output_text: The impact of crystal packing forces and modifications in ligand sets on the planarity of Cu(II) complexes is essential in controlling their deviation from square planarity. The electronic energy and its relationship to the distortion along the \(b_{2u}\) parent mode (in \(D_{4h}\)) can also provide insight into the behavior of these complexes. For instance, distortion along this mode lowers energy for square planar complexes, leading to an imaginary value for the \(b_{2u}\) mode. In contrast, for CuPc, the ligand field and the aromatic planar structure of the Pc ligand prevent distortions along this mode, resulting in an entic state that opposes ligand-metal bond ionicity. However, this advantage is counterbalanced by the ionicity and less rigid coordination provided by N-based ligands.

results.input_text: In relation, significant efforts have been guided toward better identifying, understanding, and quantifying entictic states,[82, 83, 84] which have traditionally been used to rationalize electron transfer properties. However, given the general nature of this description, it is being extended toother scenarios, including photochemistry and catalysis [85, 86, 87, 88, 89]. Strain effects have also been discussed in the context of both ground and excited states and their contributions to the coherence properties in solid state qubits (e.g, vacancies in diamond) [10, 11, 12, 90]. Thus, engineering ligand field strain and rigidity into covalent environments will be useful for advancing the geometric and electronic structural contributions to the quantum coherence of transition metal complexes, and the model outlined here can guide these future investigations.
results.output_text: Over the years, substantial efforts have been made to adequately identify, comprehend and quantify enticing states, traditionally used to explain particular electron transfer properties. Nevertheless, this description has now found applications in several other scenarios, such as photochemistry and catalysis [85, 86, 87, 88, 89]. In addition, recent research has investigated the influence of strain on both ground and excited states in the context of solid-state qubits, including vacancies in diamond [10, 11, 12, 90]. Engineering ligand field strain and rigidity into covalent environments holds immense potential in advancing the geometrical and electronic structural contributions to quantum coherence in transition metal complexes. Therefore, we anticipate that future investigations in this domain will benefit from the model outlined here.

The spin-phonon coupling terms of minimalized \(D_{4h}\)/\(D_{2d}\) [CuCl\({}_{4}\)] [2]- and \(C_{4v}\) [VOC\({}_{4}\)] [2]- complexes translate onto Cu(II)- and V(IV)-based molecular qubits and are dominated by three major factors: 1) the magnitude of the metal-based SOC constant, 2) the initial magnitude and gradient of change in ground state orbital angular momentum, which is governed by the ligand field excited state energies, and 3) dynamic relativistic nephelauxetic contributions, including the initial magnitude and gradient in the covalency of the ligand-metal bonds. Factors 1) and 3) are directly related, as covalency further reduces the SOC constant of a metal in a complex relative to that of the free ion. LFT expressions derived here predict spin-phonon coupling terms in both odd and even modes are important to consider for decoherence times (equation 5). However, odd modes such as the totally symmetric stretch play a key role for decoherence times. We have further shown how the LFT expressions and thus spin-phonon coupling terms (equations 6 and 7) can be directly related to spectroscopic observables and calculable quantities. For Cu(II), key geometric and symmetry factors, including ligand field strain, significantly lower excited state coupling terms while simultaneously increasing orbital overlap and ligand-metal covalency. Importantly, all factors relating to excited state SOC and covalency need to be evaluated when comparing spin-phonon coupling terms, including local mode contributions to \(T_{I}\) and \(T_{m}\) relaxation times, of various metal complexes. The model outlined here provides a means to quantify spin-phonon coupling terms for given vibrational modes for any S = \(\nicefrac{{1}}{{2}}\) molecule, providing a powerful means to benchmark current and future qubit candidates. The further discovery of room temperature coherent materials will provide exciting opportunities to develop fundamental structure-function correlations for spin-phonon coupling in transition metal complexes.

The LFT expressions derived from this study reveal three essential factors, including the metal-based spin-orbit coupling constant, the gradient of change in ground state orbital angular momentum, and dynamic relativistic nephelauxetic contributions (such as changes in the covalency of ligand-metal bonds). The key geometric and symmetry factors, like ligand field strain, significantly alter the excited state coupling terms while simultaneously increasing orbital overlap and ligand-metal covalency. All of the factors relating to excited state SOC and covalency need to be scrutinized while comparing the spin-phonon coupling terms across different metal complexes. By using the model outlined in this study, researchers can effortlessly quantify spin-phonon coupling terms for any S = 1/2 molecule. The findings of this study offer a powerful approach to benchmark and investigate current and future qubit candidates, which may lead to exciting prospects to construct fundamental structure-function relationships in transition metal complexes. results.input_text: Synthetic challenges toward anomalous structures and electronic states often involve handling problems such as insolubility in common organic solvents and oxidative degradation under aerobic conditions. We designed benzo-annulated aza[n]helicenes, which benefit from both the suppressed elevation of HOMO energies and high solubility due to hydrogen-bonding with solvent molecules to overcome these challenges. This strategy enabled the synthesis of six new aza[n]helicenes ([n]AHs) of different lengths (n = 9-19) from acyclic precursors via one-shot oxidative fusion reactions. The structures of all the synthesized aza[n]helicenes were determined by X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis, and their electrochemical potentials were measured by cyclic voltammetry. Among the synthesized aza[n]helicenes, [17]AH and [19]AH are the first hetero-helicenes with a triple-layered helix. The noncovalent interaction (NCI) plots confirm the existence of an effective n-n interaction between the layers. The absorption and fluorescence spectra red-shifted as the helical lengths increased, without any distinct saturation points. The optical resolutions of _N_-butylated [9]AH, and [11]AH were accomplished and their circular dichroism (CD) and circularly polarized luminescence (CPL) were measured. Thus, the structural, (chir)optical, and electrochemical properties of the aza[n]helicenes were comprehensively analyzed.
