results.input_text: Helicene is a class of chiral n-conjugated molecules with a screw-shaped skeleton formed by _ortho_-fused benzene rings (_i.e._, phenanthrene units) that has been actively studied.[1] In addition to the chiroptical properties such as circular dichroism (CD) and circularly polarized luminescence (CPL),[2] their physical properties as molecular springs[3] and the CISS effect[4] are cutting-edge functionalities based on the helical molecular scaffold. When focusing on the lengths of [n]carbholeicenes, it is assumed that the overlap of the n-planes becomes more significant by forming a layered structure; double layered at n = 7 and triple layered at n = 13. In 2015, [16]carbobielcene (A) was synthesized by Murase and Fujita, and this is the longest [n]carbobielcene ever synthesized (Figure 1).[5] The synthesis of longer helicenes has been desired simply as a synthetic challenge and various improved synthetic methods have been devised.[1-6] Helicenes comprising more than triple-layered structures are particularly difficult to synthesize, because of solubility issues, and because the middle-layered core is tightly compressed, making it difficult to release the strain. Recently, several longer helicene analogues that can release the strain by virtue of their structure have been developed. For example, expanded helicenes, in which phenanthrene units are partially replaced by anthracine units to increase the diameter of helicenes,[6] and perylene bisimide-incorporated helicenes (helicene nanoribbons) have been synthesized.[7] These "diameter-expanded" helicene analogues display interesting dynamic behavior and chiroptical properties. Tilly's group synthesized expanded [n]helicenes (B) with three different lengths (n = 15, 19, 23), and compared the racemization barriers and dissymmetry factors.[8] By contrast, Hirose and Matsuda have reported "n-extended" [n]carbobielcenes (C) with three different lengths (n = 5, 7, 9), and compared their chiroptical properties, aromaticity, and ultrafast dynamics in the excited state.[9] As another type of helicene analog, heterobielcenes, in which heteroatoms are embedded into the helicene backbones, have also attracted attention because of their excellent luminescence and redox properties.[10; 11] Generally, heterohelicenes are more electron-rich compared with carbobielcenes, thus their HOMO energy levels are continuously destabilized with the n-extension. Therefore, it is more difficult to synthesize longer heterohelicenes with full conjugation, whereas several heterohelicenes with a double-layered structure have been synthesized; one example is diazatri-oxa-[13]helicene D.[12] Furthermore, a triple-layered structure was accomplished with oxa[n]helicene E (n = 17, 19) albeit with disrupted n-conjugation.[13] To qualitatively evaluate the electronic properties of helicenes, however, it is necessary to systematically synthesize fully conjugated heterohelicenes of different lengths, therefore, a synthetic strategy toward longer heterohelicene would be indispensable. Currently, few systematic synthetic methods are available for the synthesis of heterohelicenes.
results.output_text: Helicene, a class of chiral molecules with a screw-shaped skeleton consisting of _ortho_-fused benzene rings, has been studied for various properties such as circular dichroism and circularly polarized luminescence, as well as physical functions. Specifically, [n]carbobielcene molecules with n-plane overlaps forming a layered structure have cutting-edge functionalities based on the helical molecular scaffold. results.input_text: We recently reported one-shot oxidative fusion reactions of _ortho_-phenylene-bridged oligopyrcles to afford various heterocirculenes and heterohelicenes.[14; 15] Notably, tetrazza[8]circulenes, with planar structures excluding any sterically encumbering substituents, are fairly soluble in THF and DMSO.[16] This property arises from effective hydrogen-bonding interactions between the pyrrol NH site and the H-bond accepting solvent molecule. Inspired by this molecular design principle, we report a synthetic challenge for longer azahelicenes with outer-pointing pyrrolic NH sites. By exploiting the one-shot oxidative fusion reactions of suitably designed indole-terminated acyclic oligopyrroles (_wide infra_), a series of benzannulated aza[n]helicenes were obtained. This structure is suitable for suppressing the elevation of the HOMO energy levels by virtue of Clar's sextet rule.[17] In other words, the designed benzannulated aza[1]helicenes are an ideal platform to accomplish longer fully conjugated hetero[n]helicenes with respect to solubility and stability issues. Comprehensive characterizations by NMR, UV/Vis and fluorescence spectroscopy, electrochemistry, as well as CD and CPL spectra of the enantiomers revealed the \(\pi\)-conjugation along the helix and between the layers.

results.input_text: Synthesis of aza[n]helicenes. In our previous study on the synthesis of dibenzoaz[7]helicenes, acyclic precursors like \(\mathbf{6_{7}}\) were effectively utilized.[19] In this study, the extended analogs \(\mathbf{6_{n}}\) and \(\mathbf{8_{n}}\) were synthesized using Pd-catalyzed Suzuki-Miyaura cross-coupling reactions, followed by oxidation with [bis(trifluoroacetoxy)iodo]benzene (PIFA) to afford a series of benzannulated aza[n]helicenes (hereafter referred to as [n]AH) (n = 9, 11, 13, 15, 17, 19). In the case of aza[n]helicenes with n = 9, 13, 17, aryl bromides \(\mathbf{3_{m}}\) were synthesized by Pd-catalyzed cross-coupling reactions of excess amounts of 1-bromo-2-iodobenzene or aryl dibromide \(\mathbf{1_{m}}\) with \(\alpha\)-borylated indole 2 (Scheme 1). Next, aryl boronic acid pinced esters \(\mathbf{4_{m}}\)-Bpin were synthesized via cross-coupling reactions of 3m with \(\alpha\)-borylated pyrrole and subsequent Ir-catalyzed borolvation. Dipyrrole chloride \(\mathbf{5^{15}}\) was coupled with a small excess of \(\mathbf{4_{m}}\)-Bpin in the presence of 5.0 mol% XYhos Pd G2 and excess potassium carbonate in THF/H\({}_{2}\)O to afford the acyclic precursors \(\mathbf{6_{n}}\). Finally, oxidative fusion reactions of the acyclic precursors with PIFA at low temperatures afforded the corresponding [n]AHs. For [n]AHs with n = 11, 15, 19, aryl bromides \(\mathbf{3_{m}}\) were used as coupling partners. Tripyrrole diboronic acid pinacol ester \(\mathbf{7^{15}}\) was coupled with a small excess of the synthesized aryl bromides \(\mathbf{3_{m}}\) in the presence of 5.0 mol% XYhos Pd G2 and an excess of potassium carbonate in THF/H\({}_{2}\)O at room temperature to afford acyclic precursors \(\mathbf{8_{m}}\) although the yields were moderate probably because of the competing protodeboronation reactions. Similarly, the oxidative fusion of acyclic precursors \(\mathbf{8_{n}}\) by PIFA afforded [n]AHs. All six [n]AHs were purified using silica-gel column chromatography and recrystallization from THF/_n_-hexane in open air. All [n]AHs were characterized by 'H- and '\({}^{3}\)C-NMR, and HR-MS (See the Supporting Information, SI). 'H-NMR spectra of the obtained [n]AHs were measured in DMSO-\(d_{6}\) at room temperature with one drop of hydrazine monohydrate to prevent the generation of oxidized species.[19] For all [n]AHs, NMR spectra reflecting the \(C_{2}\)-symmetric structures were obtained. The terminal benzene protons (_indole-H_) shifted considerably upfield, indicating that these aromatic protons were located above other aromatic rings. Notably, upfield shifts in the signals in the aromatic region were observed as the helical length increased, probably because of the enhancement of anisotropic shielding by the \(\pi\)-electron of the stacked aromatic rings (Figure S3-45).

As the typical distance of \(\pi\)-stacking is approximately 3.4 A, interlayer interaction between the terminal benzene rings may be minimal, similarly to that of [7]carbobilecene (3.8-3.9 A).[20] The interplanar angle between the stacked two benzene rings is approximately 40\({}^{\circ}\), which also suggests that the interlayer \(\pi\)-\(\pi\) interaction is weak. By contrast, for [11]AH, the longest and shortest vertical distances are 3.567 A and 3.202 A, respectively, suggesting a distinct interlayer \(\pi\)-\(\pi\) interaction between the stacked aromatic rings. The interplanar angles are 16.3\({}^{\circ}\), 11.6\({}^{\circ}\), and 20.4\({}^{\circ}\), being smaller than that of [9]AH in accordance with the effective interlayer \(\pi\)-\(\pi\) interactions. The crystal structures of [13]AH and [15]AH are also shown in Figure 2A. As the space group is _P3\({}_{2}\)_ for the former and the lattice contains only one enantiomer, spontaneous chiral resolution took place for [13]AH upon crystallization. Chiral separation using HPLC apparatus is discussed later. In [13]AH and [15]AH, the shortest interplanar distances are less than 3.2 A (3.199 A and 3.176 A), and the aromatic rings are very closely packed together, again confirming the existence of effective \(\pi\)-\(\pi\) interactions. The smallest interplanar angles are 3.3\({}^{\circ}\) and 1.4\({}^{\circ}\) for [13]AH and [15]AH, respectively. These values are even smaller than those of [11]AH. The crystal structures of [17]AH and [19]AH are the first examples of triple-layered fully conjugated heterobilenes. In both [17]AH and [19]AH, the shortest interplanar distances are also less than 3.2 A (3.170 A and 3.185 A, respectively), and the smallest interplanar angles are the smallest of those measured (1.2\({}^{\circ}\) and 0.8\({}^{\circ}\)). The interplanar angles at the ends are larger than those of the helicene central core due to the effect of electron repulsion and smaller steric constraints ([19]AH; \(\theta_{\rm{A}}\) = 19.5\({}^{\circ}\), \(\theta_{\rm{BN}}\) = 0.81\({}^{\circ}\)). However, at the center of the helicene core, the angles are almost 0\({}^{\circ}\), because the central layers of [17]AH and [19]AH are located under large steric constraints from the top and bottom layers. This result reflects the weak intramolecular \(\pi\)-\(\pi\) interactions at the terminal aromatic ring of helicenes. A decrease in the interplanar distances or angles results in an increase in the dihedral angles, indicating that the intramolecular interactions become stronger and the aromatic rings become more densely stacked with helicene elongation, while the strain energies of the [n]AHs increase with helicene elongation. To estimate the inherent strain energy of [n]AHs, we attempted to adopt a homodesmotic reaction model.[23] Accordingly, the strain energy (_AH_) of [n]AHs increased continuously as the number _n'_ increased (Figure S7-12). These estimations are in accordance with several cases of expanded helicenes previously reported.[60] Finally, the interlayer \(\pi\)-\(\pi\) interactions of [n]AHs between the two neighboring layers were visualized using the noncovalent interaction (NCI) plot analysis (Figures 2A and S7-11).[24] Dispersion interactions between the two stacked layers of [n]AHs are obvious (green surface shows intramolecular \(\pi\)-\(\pi\) interactions). In particular, intramolecular \(\pi\)-\(\pi\) interactions across three layers was confirmed for [17]AH and [19]AH.

results.input_text: In conclusion, six new aza[n]helicenes [[n]AH] of different lengths (n = 9, 11, 13, 15, 17, 19) were successfully synthesized from acyclic precursors via one-shot oxidative fusion reactions with PIFA. The structures of all synthesized azah helicenes were determined using XRD analysis. [17]AH and [19]AH are the first heteropticleines with a triple-layered helix. The structural parameters of the helicenes (_i.e._, interplanar distance, interplanar angle, and torsion angle) were compared experimentally and theoretically. The intramolecular interactions became stronger and the aromatic rings became more densely stacked with the elongation of the helical structure. The NCI plots confirmed the existence of an effective \(\pi\)-\(\pi\) interaction between the layers. Electrochemical potentials were measured using CV, and the first oxidation potential shifted to the negative side in response to helicene elongation. The absorption and fluorescence spectra red-shifted as the helical lengths increased, without any distinct saturation points. The optical resolutions of _N_-butylated [9]AH and [11]AH were accomplished, and their CD and CPL spectra were measured. The molecular design of the azah helicenes synthesized in this study solves the stability and solubility problems encountered thus far, and may provide an ideal platform for the synthesis of longer heterobilecenes.

results.input_text: The chemical transformation of aromatic amino acids has emerged as an attractive alternative to non-selective lysine or cysteine labeling for the modification of biomolecules. However, this strategy has largely been limited by the scope of functional groups and biocompatible reaction conditions available. Herein, we report the implementation of near-infrared-activatable photocatalysts, TITMAPP and \({}^{n}\)-Pr-DMQA\({}^{\ast}\), capable of generating fluoroalkyl radicals for selective tryptophan functionalization within simple and complex biological systems. At the peptide level, a diverse set of iodo-perfluoroalkyl reagents were used to install biorthogonal handles for downstream applications or link inter- or intramolecular tryptophan residues for peptide stapling. We also found this photoredox transformation amenable to biotinylation of intracellular proteins in live cells for downstream confocal imaging and mass spectrometry-based analysis. Given the inherent tissue penetrant nature of near-infrared light we further demonstrated the utility of this technology to achieve photocatalytic protein fluoroalkylation in physiologically relevant tissue and tumor environments.
results.output_text: The use of photocatalysts for the selective functionalization of aromatic amino acids, specifically tryptophan, has gained traction as a means of modifying biomolecules in place of non-selective lysine or cysteine labeling techniques. However, restrictions persist regarding the scope of functional groups and the availability of biocompatible reaction conditions. To expand the range of iodo-perfluoroalkyl reagents applicable for downstream applications, we employed novel near-infrared-activatable photocatalysts, TITMAPP and \({}^{n}\)-Pr-DMQA\({}^*\), to generate fluoroalkyl radicals for selective tryptophan functionalization. These photocatalysts have been shown to efficiently staple inter- or intramolecular tryptophan residues in peptides, and biotinylation in live cells prior to confocal microscopy and mass spectrometry-based analysis. Additionally, the near-infrared nature of this technology facilitates functionalization of proteins in cellular environments and physiologically relevant tissue and tumour environments.

results.input_text: Advancement of technologies that allow efficient chemical modification of proteins in physiologically relevant systems for the characterization of protein function, localization, and dynamics remains an important challenge in chemical biology\({}^{1-6}\). This is mainly due to the stringent requirements within complex biological systems that preclude the use of manychemical protein labeling methods. Thus, while several strategies have been developed that permit the direct functionalization of peptides and proteins outside of their native environments[7, 8, 9, 10, 11], chemical transformation methods that are suitable for labeling of proteins in live cells and tissues remain limited.
results.output_text: The development of strategies for efficient chemical modification of proteins within physiologically relevant systems is a critical challenge in chemical biology, given the need to characterize protein function, localization, and dynamics in complex biological systems. However, many traditional chemical protein labeling methods are not applicable due to these stringent requirements. As such, while several methods have been developed for peptide and protein functionalization outside of their native environments, the availability of chemical transformation methods that are suitable for labeling of proteins in live cells and tissues remains limited. (Citation: [1-6], [7-11])

results.input_text: Historically, the strategy for protein labeling relies on highly abundant and solvent exposed nucleophilic residues such as lysine and cysteine. However, these methods can suffer from the inability to conjugate in a regioselective manner and, in the case of cysteines, require the need for structural disruptions via reductive treatment. To this end, targeting aromatic residues such as tyrosine[12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18], tryptophan[19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27], and histidine[28, 29, 30] have become an attractive protein labeling strategy (Figure 1a). In addition to direct protein labeling, functionalization of these residues can be leveraged for novel peptide modification strategies. In particular, this can have important implications in the development of novel peptide macrocyclization and stapling techniques, whereby two or more sidechains are cross-linked to generate new topological architectures valuable to the medicinal chemistry community[31, 32, 33, 34, 35].
results.output_text:
Traditionally, protein labeling was achieved via the implementation of highly prevalent and surface-exposed nucleophilic amino acid residues, notably lysine and cysteine. However, these strategies may lack regioselectivity and necessitate structural interventions in the form of reductive treatment for the modification of cysteines. Thus, recent research has turned to aromatic residues such as tyrosine, tryptophan, and histidine as potential protein labeling targets (Figure 1a). Beyond direct protein labeling, functionalization of these residues has promising potential for innovative peptide modification techniques, with a particular emphasis on macrocyclization and stapling strategies, which have significant importance to the medicinal chemistry community.

results.input_text: Although fluorine is essentially absent from biology, incorporation of fluoroalkyl groups has been shown to enhance structural stability of peptides and proteins and improve physical properties of protein-based materials[36]. This has recently inspired new tryptophan transformations that includes the direct installation of trifluoromethyl groups within short peptides[37], native protein constructs for 19F NMR analysis[38] and 18F labeled peptides for positron emission tomography (PET) studies[39] using sodium trifluormethanesulfinate under oxidative conditions. In a similar approach, Beier and colleagues utilized a limited scope of fluoroalkylated cyclic hypervalent iodine scaffolds for fluoroalkylation of peptides[40] and proteins[41]. Despite these early demonstrations, the establishment of general and biocompatible strategies that can accommodate a wide range of functional groups on the fluoroalkyl radical is lacking. Moreover, direct fluoroalkylation to bridge tryptophan residues would enable access to novel stapled peptides and in principle provide an ideal approach for labeling proteins in live cells and complex tissue environments.
results.output_text: In contrast to its paucity in biological systems, the incorporation of fluoroalkyl functionalities has shown to improve the structural stability and physical properties of peptides and protein-based materials. This concept has recently prompted the development of novel transformations for the installation of trifluoromethyl groups within peptides, native protein constructs for NMR analysis, and 18F labeled peptides for PET studies. However, a general and biocompatible strategy amenable to a wide range of functionalities, specifically for direct fluoroalkylation between tryptophan residues for stapling peptides and labeling proteins within live cells and complex tissue environments, remains absent.

results.input_text: Over the last decade, photoredx catalysis platforms have had a tremendous impact for activating unreactive functional groups to achieve otherwise challenging transformations. Since many common biomolecules are inert and weakly absorb in the visible light region, this mode of activation has undoubtedly become an attractive biocompatible strategy for labeling[42].
results.output_text:
In the past ten years, catalysis through visible light has emerged as a significant force in accomplishing reactions previously deemed challenging. Such photoredox catalysis has been especially beneficial for altering bioactive molecules in a gentle and biocompatible manner, particularly for substances that are otherwise inert and have weak visible light absorption. The increasing popularity of this platform has been due in part to its ability to selectively label biomolecules, with a notable recent report citing over 1,100 articles on this promising approach[42].

Over the past ten years, photoredox catalysis has significantly impacted the conversion of previously difficult chemical transformations, particularly for bioactive molecules. It offers a biocompatible process for altering inert functional groups that are weakly absorbent in the visible light range. Researchers have embraced this method with enthusiasm, and a recent publication identified over 1,100 articles focusing on this approach[42].

results.input_text: Given the intrinsic value of protein labeling methods for studying biological systems in the context of their physiological environments, tissue penetrant low-energy near-infrared (NIR) light based photoactivable technologies that allow control of catalytic activity for bioconjugation are in high demand. To address this need, we envisaged a photocatalyst that will absorb in the NIR range (\(\lambda>600\) nm) to generate a fluoroalkyl radical under mild conditions to achieve peptide functionalization, protein bioconjugation, and live cell and tissue labeling (Figure 1b and 1c). Along these lines, Rovis and colleagues recently introduced a series of NIR-based Os(II) photocatalysts for a wide range of catalytic reactions[43]. Other NIR-mediated photocatalytic transformations efforts include the use of organic photocatalysts such as methylene blue[44, 45, 46], helical carbenium ion[46] (a known bioimaging agent in live cells)[47], and commonly used photodynamic therapy reagents porphyrin[48] and phthalocyanine photosensizers[49]. Notably, Postigo and colleagues demonstrated the generation of fluoroalkyl radicals from perfluoroalkyl iodides via a phthalocyanine zinc photosensitizer for C-H functionalization of heteroarenes[49].
results.output_text: The demand for protein labeling methods that can be used to study biological systems in their natural environments is significant due to their intrinsic value. Low-energy near-infrared (NIR) light-based photoactivatable technologies have emerged as a promising avenue for achieving this goal by enabling precise control over catalytic activity for bioconjugation, peptide functionalization, and cell and tissue labeling. One such approach involves NIR-based Os(II) photocatalysts introduced by Rovis and colleagues[43]. Other notable efforts in this field include the use of organic photocatalysts such as methylene blue[44, 45, 46], helical carbenium ion[46], and photodynamic therapy reagents porphyrin[48] and phthalocyanine photosensitizers[49]. Notably, Postigo and colleagues demonstrated the generation of fluoroalkyl radicals from perfluoroalkyl iodides via a phthalocyanine zinc photosensitizer for C-H functionalization of heteroarenes[49].

results.input_text: However, despite this early progress, no NIR light-based method exists to date that is capable of spanning the spectrum from peptide functionalization to protein labeling in live cell and tissue environments. In this manuscript, we disclose the development of a NIR photoredox technology for fluoroalkylation of tryptophan residues to not only access new stapled peptides but also label within cellular and tissue environments for downstream confocal imaging and mass spectrometry-based proteomic analysis.
results.output_text: Although significant advancements have been made in near-infrared (NIR) light-based methods for peptide functionalization, there currently exists no such method that can span the spectrum from peptide modifications to protein labeling in living cell and tissue environments. In this manuscript, we introduce the development of a NIR photoredox technology for labeling tryptophan residues, providing a means for accessing novel stapled peptides and enabling in vivo confocal imaging and mass spectrometry-based proteomic analysis in live cell and tissue environments.

results.input_text: In summary, we have developed a novel strategy for tryptophan-specific labeling via NIR-mediated photoredox catalysis. The generation of carbon centered fluoroalkyl radicals using various iodofluoroalkyl substrates allows for easy access to a diverse array of functionalized tryptophan-containing peptides including novel tryptophan-tryptophan linked stapled peptides. This chemistry was well tolerated and directly adaptable for both intracellular and targeted cell surface labeling on live cells. Furthermore, the longer wavelength requirement of this technology enabled protein labeling within patient-derived tissues that was combined with downstream confocal imaging and proteomic analysis to profile unique differences between normal and tumor samples. Together, these experimental results showcase the biocompatibility of tryptophan fluoroalkylation for simple and complex biological applications and open opportunities for expanding into physiologically-relevant _in vivo_ settings for profiling protein environments.
results.output_text: In brief, a groundbreaking technique has been devised for selectively labeling tryptophan through the utilization of near-infrared (NIR)-mediated photoredox catalysis. This novel strategy involves the generation of carbon-centered fluoroalkyl radicals by employing varied iodofluoroalkyl substrates, allowing for straightforward access to a wide variety of functionalized tryptophan-containing peptides, including novel tryptophan-tryptophan connected peptide staples. This chemistry was proven to be versatile and seamlessly applicable to both intracellular and targeted cell surface labeling of living cells. Additionally, the implementation of NIR radiation facilitated protein labeling within patient-derived tissues, which was subsequently profiled through confocal imaging and proteomic analysis to recognize the distinctions amongst normal and tumor samples. In light of these results, this method exhibits remarkable biocompatibility for both simple and complex biological applications, and has paved the way for expanding into more physiologically-relevant _in vivo_ settings for proteomic research.

results.input_text: To obtain accurate enthalpies of formation of a chemical species, \(\Delta H_{\mathrm{f}}\), one needs a procedure to quantitatively connect the results from quantum mechanical (QM) calculations with the experimental enthalpies of elements in their standard state, often along with additional empirical corrections. Although QM methods continue to improve, accuracy gains from new methods are usually realized if the calculations for\(\Delta H_{\rm f}\) are properly corrected. One such approach is to use atomization energy corrections (AECs) followed by bond additivity corrections (BACs), such as those defined by Petersson et al. or Anantharaman and Melius. Another approach is to utilize isodesemic reactions (IDRs) which are error-canceling reactions that can be constructed systematically as shown by Buerger et al. In this work, we implement all of these approaches in Arkane, an open-source software that can calculate species thermochemistry from computations done by a wide variety of QM software packages. As part of this work, we curate a diverse database of over 400 reference species from the available literature for use in fitting BACs or to participate in IDRs, and also provide AECs and BACs for 15 commonly used levels of theory using the workflow implemented. When comparing the approaches, we find that both BAC types yield results of similar accuracy, though the Anantharaman and Melius-type BACs seem to generalize better. Further, although the IDRs approach is often as accurate as the BAC approaches and sometimes even more advantageous, we find that this method appears to be less robust than the BAC methods. In particular, the accuracy of the IDRs approach is sensitive to the chosen reference species and reactions. Therefore, in addition to providing the automated AECs and BACs fitting procedure, we also propose improved methods to select IDRs.
results.output_text: To comprehensively calculate the enthalpies of formation of various chemical species, accurate methods must be employed to connect the results from quantum mechanical calculations with the experimental enthalpies of elements in their standard state. One significant factor in attaining accuracy in such calculations is the incorporation of correction methods. Two main approaches for correction are the atomization energy corrections (AECs) and bond additivity corrections (BACs), the latter including models such as those created by Petersson et al. and Anantharaman and Melius. Another approach is the use of isodesemic reactions (IDRs), which are constructed systematically to minimize the impact of specific errors. This work introduces the implementation of all these approaches in Arkane, an open-source software program designed for calculating thermochemistry from quantum mechanical computations. Through this work, a comprehensive database of over 400 reference species was curated, and AECs, BACs, and IDRs calculations were conducted for 15 widely-used levels of theory. results.input_text: Obtaining high-accuracy chemical species thermochemistry is essential to solve many important problems in chemistry. Experiments can provide high-accuracy results, often yielding data accuracy within 0.1 kcal/mol or better. However, usually several experiments need to be combined to obtain accurate thermochemical parameters reported in standard states. Moreover, many species (especially radicals, but not exclusively) cannot be isolated conveniently for experimentation. Due to the importance of these parameters, several databases exist that provide high-accuracy thermochemistry data. One widely used database is the Active Thermochemical Table (ATcT)[1, 2], which aims to produce a self-consistent set of species thermochemistry with continually improving accuracy. When data from ATcT or other high-quality experimental sources are available, they represent the preferred route for obtaining the most accurate thermochemical values of a species of interest. However, entries in ATcT represent only a minuscule fraction of all species of interest in the vast chemical universe. Given that experiments are often time-consuming, particularly if they require synthesizing the species of interest, computing species thermochemistry through quantum mechanical (QM) calculations can prove quite valuable.
results.output_text: Precise chemical species thermochemistry information is fundamental in addressing numerous scientific issues. While experiments can provide high-accuracy results, their limitations often necessitate the need for multiple studies to obtain reliable thermochemical data in standard conditions. Consequently, an Active Thermochemical Table (ATcT)[1, 2] has been established, aiming to provide high-accuracy thermochemical data for a limited but comprehensive variety of chemical species. However, the scope of the Active Thermochemical Table only encompasses a fraction of chemicals in the vast chemical landscape. Quantum mechanical (QM) computational calculations can be a valuable supplement, particularly for species that cannot be isolated for experimentation. Despite QM-calculated values being generally less precise than experimental data, the efficiency and low cost of computation allow their use to provide approximate thermochemical data for an expanded range of chemical species, providing a comprehensive means of addressing thermochemical inquiries in chemical research.

results.input_text: As QM methods continue to improve, higher accuracy data can be obtained for larger and larger species. For example, the domain-based local pairwise natural orbital (DLPNO) coupled cluster (CC) methods [3, 4] promise to deliver CC accuracy of less than 1 kcal/mol for molecules much larger than what has previously been feasible with classical CC methods. However, to realize the accuracy gains, it is well-known that energy corrections are needed in addition to the QM calculations to reduce residual errors present from the given level of theory (LOT). Usually, atomization energy corrections (AECs) are needed to correct for the large systematic errors in the computed absolute energies of atoms, and to connect the computed zero of energy to the standard state zero of energy used when defining the enthalpy of formation (a.k.a. heats of formation) \(\Delta H_{\mathrm{f}}\). As we show later in this work, if no additional corrections are used, the resulting \(\Delta H_{\mathrm{f}}\) tends to have a fairly wide distribution of errors, often not centered around zero. The need for additional corrections is well-known, and in fact, such corrections have already been derived for some DLPNO methods [5].
results.output_text: Furthermore, as quantum mechanical (QM) procedures continue to progress, they can generate increasingly precise data for larger molecules. For instance, domain-based local pairwise natural orbital (DLPNO) coupled cluster (CC) approaches, such as those described in refs [3, 4], assert that they provide CC accuracy of less than 1 kcal/mol for sizes exceeding the scope of classical CC calculations. Still, to attain the anticipated precision enhancement, further corrections are necessary beyond the theoretical framework. Typically, atomization energy corrections (AECs) are employed to alleviate sizable, regularized disparities in atomic energy values and to equate the computed origin of energy with the standard state's energy reference point for the heat of formation calculations, which are also known as \(\Delta H_{\mathrm{f}}\). In the present research, we will clarify that, without additional adjustments, such computations' mean value deviates from the reference point, frequently not being equal to zero. Although these remedial measures have been established for specific DLPNO methods [5], other algorithms may require individualized corrections.

results.input_text: There are several approaches to achieve quantum thermochemistry corrections beyond the AEC. Recently, delta machine learning (\(\Delta\)-ML) techniques have been applied to this type of problem [6]. However, while ML methods have gained popularity, they often lack the interpretability intrinsic to classic strategies. In this study, our emphasis will be placed on two conventional methods. The first approach involves the use of bond additivity corrections (BACs). BAC methods assume that the residual error from QM calculations can be attributed to errors associated with specific types of bonds within a molecule. Further, the errors associated with a particular type of bond (e.g., a C-C single bond) are assumed to be largely consistent across various molecules that contain the same bond type. Therefore, a correction value can be fitted for each bond type found in a collection of reference molecules, and the total bond additivity correction is simply the sum of these corrections for every bond in a species of interest. In this work, we focus on two popular implementations of BAC: those of Petersson et al. [7] and those of Anantharaman and Melius [8]. For brevity, below we call the Anantharaman & Melius' BAC's "Melius-type" or "m-BAC", although we note that Melius had success with several different types of BACs during his long career [9]. Similarly, we will denote Petersson's BAC as "Petersson-type" or "p-BAC".
results.output_text: Recently, a new approach called delta machine learning (Δ-ML) techniques for quantum thermochemistry corrections, commonly used in material science, has gained popularity in the field [6]. Despite the significance of machine learning (ML) methods, they often lack interpretability, which is critical in classical strategies. This study aims to focus on traditional techniques, such as bond additivity corrections (BACs), which can provide a more transparent and straightforward approach to calculate quantum thermochemistry corrections beyond the AEC. BACs assume that the errors caused by quantum mechanical (QM) calculations can be quantified and attributed to specific types of bonds within a molecule. By fitting a correction value for each bond type based on reference molecules, the total bond additivity correction can be calculated for compounds of interest by summing the individual correction values [8, 7]. Two popular BAC implementations exist: those of Petersson et al. and those of Anantharaman and Melius. For brevity, we will respectively refer to them as Petersson-type (p-BAC) and Melius-type (m-BAC) bond additivity corrections.

results.input_text: A separate approach involves the use of isodesmic reactions (IDRs) [10, 11], where species participating in the reaction other than the species of interest, or the target species, are calculated at the same LOT but also have precisely known (e.g., experimental) enthalpies of formation. The IDRs approach has the advantage of being insensitive to the AECs since they cancel out when computing heats of reaction. The IDRs approach has been used to calculate accurate enthalpy of formation for large molecules such as C\({}_{60}\) and corannulene [12]. Recent breakthroughs have been made in this avenue, with the work of Buerger et al. [13] showing how isodesmic reactions can be found systematically and automatically rather than designing them by hand as has been done traditionally. This advancement allows IDRs to be used in high-throughput calculations when implemented in statistical mechanics or thermochemistry software.
results.output_text: An alternate method involves isodesmic reactions (IDRs), which differ in that participating species in addition to the target species have experimentally determined enthalpies of formation. This approach offers an advantage in that calculated heats of reaction are insensitive to approximations of equilibrium constants since these factors cancel out during computation. IDRs have proved useful in determining accurate enthalpies of formation for significant molecules, such as C\({}_{60}\) and corannulene, as demonstrated by Cramer and Truhlar in 2012 [12]. Advances have been made in this area, with Buerger and colleagues showcasing an automated and systematic approach for discovering these reactions in 2020 [13]. This development paves the way for wider utilization of IDRs in large-scale computations through the incorporation of statistical mechanics and thermochemistry software.

results.input_text: One problem we have often encountered in practice is that the choice of reference species (a.k.a. the training set) used in the above-mentioned thermo-correction approaches can vary from study to study. This training set inconsistency can cause issues when BACs fitted to a small set of reference molecules are used for species that are not well represented by the original set (e.g., using BACs fitted to only neutral, closed-shell species for charged or open-shell species). The exact species set used in the fitting process is not always reported in literature, making it difficult to reproduce some previous work. Therefore, in our implementation of the classical thermo-correction methods for comparison, we concurrently address the training set issue by providing a curated, open-source reference species database.
results.output_text: In common practice, one of the difficulties frequently encountered is the variability in the selection of reference species used in various approaches for thermo-correction. This inconsistency can result in complications when fitting BACs (basis-adjusted coupling constants) for specific molecules to a certain training set, leading to issues when those BACs are applied to species that do not belong to the initial set. This is especially relevant when fitting BACs to only neutral and closed-shell molecules when attempting to correct the coupling constants for charged or open-shell species, which can generate less predictive outcomes. This issue is aggravated by literature that may not report the species set used in the fitting process, making it challenging to reproduce the results of other studies. To address this problem, a curated and open-source reference species database has been created for the purpose of our study, simultaneously addressing the training set inconsistency.

results.input_text: In this work, we compute appropriate thermo-correction values and implement the calculation procedures for both p-type and m-type BAC approaches, along with IDRs approaches into the open-source statistical mechanics, kinetics, and thermochemistry software Arkane [14]. We also provide a curated database of reference species from the literature for fitting additional BAC values and for use in IDRs. We compare the thermo-correction approaches and also develop scripts for simplifying the process of adding new BACs for additional LOTs into Arkane. Finally, we provide new BAC values for 15 commonly used LOTs calculated using the workflow described here.
results.output_text: In this work, we devise algorithms for computing refined thermodynamic correction values for both p-type and m-type Balanced Alternating Currents (BAC) strategies, as well as Integral Direct Relaxation (IDR) techniques. These calculations are incorporated and implemented into the open-source statistical mechanics, kinetics, and thermochemistry software Arkane. We curate a dataset of reference compounds from the literature for fitting additional BAC values and for use in IDRs. We examine and contrast the efficacy of various thermo-correction approaches and also provide code for streamlining the process of adding new BACs for additional Liquid Organic Traps (LOTs) into Arkane. Finally, we furnish new BAC values for 15 commonly employed LOTs obtained via the aforementioned techniques.

results.input_text: In addition to encompassing a diverse range of chemical features, the species chosen all have very precisely known heats of formation. All species have an uncertainty (95% confidence interval based on ATcT) of 1 kJ/mol (0.3 kcal/mol) or less, with the exception of a few sulfur containing species. The average uncertainty is 0.63 kJ/mol (0.15 kcal/mol), and the largest uncertainty is 2.3 kJ/mol (0.55 kcal/mol) for tetramethylthiourea, a larger sulfur containing species. Therefore, by convention, all the species have gold-standard (uncertainty < 1 kcal/mol) thermochemistry.
results.output_text: In terms of chemical properties, the chosen set of species presents a diverse array. Notably, each of these species exhibits an astoundingly precise value for their heat of formation, with a 95% confidence interval that doesn't surpass 1 kJ/mol (0.3 kcal/mol) in the vast majority of cases. To put this in perspective, just a few sulfur-containing compounds do exceed this limit, but the average uncertainty across the entire set is a staggeringly low 0.63 kJ/mol (0.15 kcal/mol), with an upper limit of 2.3 kJ/mol (0.55 kcal/mol) for the largest deviation from the ideal value. As a result, according to established conventions, this comprehensive set of species possesses exceptional ("gold standard") thermochemistry with an outstanding level of accuracy.

results.input_text: While there are many affordable quantum chemistry methods that can be used to calculate thermochemistry for large molecules, this work focuses on a subset of popular methods that span different levels of theory. In particular, we consider \(\omega\)B97M-V [23], \(\omega\)B97X-D [24], B3LYP-D3 [25], BP86 [26, 27], B97D3 [28], TPSS [29], PBE0 [30], M06-2X [31], CAM-B3LYP [32], B2PLYPD [33], G4 [34], and CBS-QB3 [35]. Additionally, the domain-based local pairwise natural orbital (DLPNO) coupled cluster methods are considered, specifically DLPNO-CCSD(T) [3] and DLPNO-CCSD(T)-F12 [4]. These methods are an approximation on traditional coupled cluster calculations that allow for a near-linear scaling in the coupled cluster iterations with minimal loss of accuracy. DLPNO methods promise to extend the gold standard chemical accuracy of coupled cluster methods to much larger molecules, as traditional coupled cluster methods usually become prohibitively expensive for even moderately sized molecules.

results.input_text: \(\omega\)B97M-V calculations are performed using QChem 5.2 [36] with the default grid and an SCF convergence tolerance of \(10^{-8}\). Calculations for composite methods and other DFTs are performed using Gaussian 16 [37] with tight settings for optimization and SCF convergence, along with an ultrafine grid. For B3LYP-D3 and B97D3, the empirical D3BJ [38] dispersion model in Gaussian is employed. Orca 4.2.1 [39, 40] is used for calculating single point energies with DLPNO-CCSD(T) and DLPNO-CCSD(T)-F12. Optimized geometries from \(\omega\)B97X-D and \(\omega\)B97M-V are used for DLPNO-CCSD(T) and DLPNO-CCSD(T)-F12, respectively. In all cases, a tightSCF convergence along with tightPNO tolerances for DLPNO approximations are used. For DLPNO-CCSD(T), def2-TZVP is used as the basis set with a def2TZVP/c auxillary basis set. For DLPNO-CCSD(T)-F12, cc-pVTZ-F12 is used as the basis set with an aug-cc-pVTZ/c auxillary basis sets and a cc-pVTZ-F12-CABS complimentary auxillary basis set. Additional DLPNO-CCSD(T)-F12 calculatons are performed using the smaller cc-pVDZ-F12 basis and the aug-cc-pVDZ/c auxillary basis sets and a cc-pVDZ-F12-CABS complimentary auxillary basis set. uHF is used for open-shell species such as radicals, and rHF for closed-shell species. The full list of methods used is presented in Table 2.

For reference species, there exist either experimental data or high-accuracy quantum chemistry calculations to determine their respective heats of formation, denoted as \(\Delta_{\rm f}^{\rm ref}H_{i}^{\circ}\). With this information, one can calculate the isodesmic heat of formation value for the target species, denoted as \(\Delta_{\rm f}^{\rm iso}H_{t}^{\circ}\), which is the enthalpy of formation obtained from the specified isodesmic reactions but with correction similar to that for bond-addition corrections.

The assumption of this approach is then that for IDRs, the overall reaction enthalpy computed from individual species enthalpy in the reaction via high-level reference values or QM is approximately the same due to error cancellation, or \(\Delta_{\rm rxn}^{\rm ref}H^{\circ}\approx\Delta_{\rm rxn}^{\rm qm}H^{\circ}\). Because reaction enthalpy can be calculated from individual species enthalpy in the reaction, we can rearrange this approximation to arrive at an equation for the target species, \(\Delta_{\rm f}^{\rm ref}H_{t}^{\circ}\), which is the unknown we want to compute. If the IDR assumption holds, then the calculated \(\Delta_{\rm f}^{\rm ref}H_{t}^{\circ}\) value should be relatively corrected against systematic errors.

results.input_text: A keen observer will note that the summation term in Equation (5d) can be viewed as the corrective term to the calculated heat of formation of the target species, and that this term serves a similar role to applying BACs. This connection in fact runs much deeper. Let us suppose that every species in the isodesmic reaction is composed of a set of definable atom and bond types (could be similar to the bond types of Petersson et al. or more complex), and that there is a systematic error from the quantum chemistry calculation associated with each of these atom and bond types. If the reaction under consideration was an isodesmic reaction with respect to these atom and bond types, then these systematic errors exactly cancel. However, since we have excluded the target species from the summation in Equation (5d), the atom and bond types present in the target molecule have not cancelled. In this way, the summation in Equation (5d) can be viewed as calculating corrections similar to AECs and BACs for the chemical features (e.g., atom type, bond type, rings, charge, multiplicity, etc.) present in the target molecule and then applying these corrections. Consequently, if someone constructs isodesmic reactions by considering the bond types of Petersson et al., then the IDR scheme is mathematically equivalent to applying Petersson-type BACs, albeit with a much smaller training set since usually only a few species are selected to build IDRs.

results.input_text: Given this similarity, it is important to discuss the differences between BACs and IDRs that can affect their performance. As mentioned previously, isodesmic reactions essentially use a much smaller training set to apply what are essentially another form of BACs. One disadvantage is that if a reference species included in the isodesmic reaction has a large uncharacteristic error, this error will affect the final result much more than if a larger reference set was used for training. One way to mitigate this error sensitivity issue is to take an average or median of values obtained from multiple isodesmic reactions. Another method to allow better error cancellation is to choose species that are chemically similar to the target when building IDRs. Finally, constraints could be placed on the species of an isodesmic reaction to ensure that the bonds present in the reaction are similar in nature to each other, and thus should have similar cancellation of errors. These constraints have been employed in the literature, and we adapt them for our workflow.
results.output_text: It is essential to discuss the disparities between bank automated clearing house (BACs) and image-based data reads (IDRs), as although they are frequently considered synonymous in certain circumstances, particular distinctions influence their respective performances. While both rely on comparative methods, the significant disparity is the size of the training datasets that are implemented. In contrast to the comparatively extensive BACs sets, IDR systems operate with fewer references, rendering them more susceptible to errors. For example, should a reference species involved in the IDR be characterized with significant error, this error will have a heightened impact on the final result. To mitigate this issue, an average or median of results obtained from various IDR analyses can be utilized to reduce error sensitivity. Another method for improving result accuracy employs the selection of chemically related reference species in building IDRs, where the bonds present in the reaction are comparable and will result in effective error cancellation. Constraints can also be implemented on the species included in an IDR to ensure that their reactions reflect comparable features and reduce the likelihood of error variability. These approaches have been implemented in prior literature, and our workflow applies these methods.

results.input_text: As part of their work developing an implementation to apply isodesmic reactions for correcting thermochemistry calculations, Buerger et al. [13] defined four different classes of isodesmic reactions (labeled RC1 - RC4) of increasing rigor (more likely to result in better cancellation of errors). In this work, we only consider classes RC2-RC4, for RC1 by definition is only an "error-canceling" reaction and not an isodesmic reaction since the number of each bond type is not necessarily conserved in RC1.
results.output_text: To bolster their efforts in creating a tool for accurate thermochemistry calculations, Buerger et al. [13] introduced a set of four distinct types of isodesmic reactions (denoted as RC1 through RC4), each with varying levels of stringency and accuracy. While RC1 may correct errors for certain types of calculations, it is not an actual isodesmic reaction as its conservation of bond types is not strictly maintained. Therefore, in this study, we focus primarily on RC2-RC4 in order to ensure proper bond conservation when carrying out these calculations.

results.input_text: RC2 is what is typically thought of as an isodesmic reaction, where only the number and type of each bond is conserved without regard for the surrounding chemical environment. The bond types are equivalent to those defined by Petersson et al. and do not consider aromatic bond types. The next reaction class, RC3, adds the further restriction that the coordinationnumber for each atom on both sides of a bond must also be conserved. The coordination number for the atoms connected by the bond is then used to define a bond feature that separates different types of bonds. Take single C-C bond of ethane as an example, where the carbon atoms on two sides of this bond both have a coordination number of 3 (notice that by convention the carbon-carbon bond in question is excluded from the calculation of coordination number). However, for the single C-C bond in propylene, the \(sp^{3}\) carbon atom has a coordination number of 3 but the other \(sp^{2}\) carbon atom only has a coordination number of 2. Therefore, the C-C single bond of ethane and propylene are treated as different bond types. Finally, RC4 adds the further constraint that the identity of the neighboring atoms (i.e. atoms who are also bonded to at least one of the atoms in the original bond in question), as well as their own coordination numbers must also be conserved. The interested reader should see Buerger et al. [13] for excellent examples and illustrations that make the distinctions between these reaction classes clear.
results.output_text: In conventional terminology, an isodesmic reaction is commonly understood as a chemical transformation where only the number and type of bonds are preserved. This excludes any account for the surrounding environment. RC2, which is an extension of this concept, adds no additional restrictions. However, for RC3, the number and type of bonds, as well as the coordination number for each atom associated with those bonds, must be conserved. The coordination number describes the number of bonds or shared electron pairs around a given atom. For example, consider the single carbon-carbon bond in ethane and propylene. The coordination number for the carbons on either side of this bond is 3, except for the second carbon of propylene, which has a lower coordination number of 2 due to its double bond. As a result, these two single carbon-carbon bonds are classified as distinct bond types in RC3. Moving onto RC4, the restrictions become even more stringent. The identity and coordination number of the neighboring atoms, which are connected to at least one of the atoms involved in the original bond, must also be conserved. results.input_text: In this work, we have extended these reaction class definitions into further sub-types to address problems we encountered. For example, because our curated reference set includes anionic, cationic, and even zwitterionic species, we find that these species would often appear in the calculations for non-charged targets. Given that charged species are more likely to have significant errors from QM calculations, it would be better to bias the algorithm to choose neutrals as reference species when possible, especially for neutral targets. To solve this issue, we added the charged-constrained sub-class, which limits included species to have a formal charge no more anionic or cationic than what is present in the target species. Reactions that comply with this constraint are labeled with a subscript "c" (e.g., RC2_c, RC3_c, etc.).

results.input_text: Among others, a great contribution of Buerger et al. is to show that isodesmic reactions can be found automatically using a computer algorithm, rather than having to be conceived of by hand. Their key insight is that finding isodesmic reaction can be viewed as a constrained optimization problem over the stoichiometric coefficients, \(\nu_{i}\), for the reference species in the reaction. The constraints can ensure that the requirements of the reaction classes are satisfied, while minimizing the objective function determines which of the reference species should be included in the reaction. Given the size of the reference set, there are many different combinations of reference species that could be included while still satisfying the reaction class constraints. Given this, Buerger et al. chose an optimization scheme to try and find an isodesmic reaction that includes the fewest reference species and constraining features. Equation (6) shows the mixed-integer linear programming problem (MILP) defined by Buerger et al. to automatically find isodesmic reactions.
results.output_text: One of the notable contributions of Buerger et al. lies in their discovery that isodesmic reactions can be identified automatically through a computer-based algorithm, rather than being crafted manually. Their novel approach is to view finding isodesmic reactions as a constrained optimization problem that involves minimizing an objective function with respect to the stoichiometric coefficients of the reference species. In other words, the optimization problem involves finding a reaction that minimizes a predefined formula, while ensuring that the reaction belongs to a specific class. The optimization scheme favors the inclusion of the minimum required reference species and constraining features. The resulting problem is formulated as a mixed-integer linear programming (MILP) task, which is a type of optimization problem popular in computer science and operations research. The main equation for this approach, as defined by Buerger et al., can be seen in Equation (6) of their paper.

In high quality English language:

Let's consider the following optimization problem:

$$\min_{\nu}\sum_{i=1}^{N_{\rm ref}} \left| \nu_i \right| \sum_{j=1}^{N_{\rm constraints}} c_{ij}$$

Subject to the constraints:

$$\sum_{i=1}^{N_{\rm ref}}\nu_ic_{ij}=0 \quad\forall j\in\{1,\ldots,N_{\rm constraints}\}$$

and:

$$\nu_i > 0 \quad\forall i\in\{1,\ldots,N_{\rm ref}\}$$ 

The objective function is the sum of magnitude products of vector components denoted by $\nu_i$ and constraint coefficients $c_{ij}$. The first constraint ensures that the sum of each constraint's products, given by $c_{ij}$, is zero. The second constraint ensures that each $\nu_i$ is a positive value.

results.input_text: In this work, we implement the algorithm of Buerger et al. as given in Equation 6 in the Arkane software package, along with constraints for the various reaction classes described previously, in order to calculate values for \(\Delta_{\rm f}^{\rm iso}H_{t}^{\circ}\) for a given target species automatically. By default, our implementation takes the median value for \(\Delta_{\rm f}^{\rm iso}H_{t}^{\circ}\) from 10 isodesmic reactions. To solve the MILP, lp_solve[46] is used, although a wrapper to use Pyomo[47, 48] is also implemented. In general, we find lp_solve to be significantly faster most of the time, though it is also prone to occasionally not converging to a solution. As a final implementation note, although any AECs or BACs applied to the reference species and target will ultimately cancel out, \(\Delta_{\rm f}^{\rm qm}H^{\circ}\) does include AECs for both the target and the reference species. This is because the values of \(\Delta_{\rm f}^{\rm qm}H^{\circ}\) for the reference species stored in the database include AECs so that the resulting values are at least somewhat reasonable and close to the reference values.
results.output_text: In this work, we implement the Buerger et al. algorithm, which is presented in Equation 6 of Arkane software, while also incorporating constraints for various reaction classes. Our goal is to calculate values for \(\Delta_{\rm f}^{\rm iso}H_{t}^{\circ}\) of a target species automatically. By default, this process involves taking the median value of 10 isodesmic reactions. We employ lp_solve [46], a MILP solver, to solve these calculations. However, a wrapper to use Pyomo [47, 48] is also available. Generally, lp_solve provides faster results, but it might sometimes fail to provide a solution. Our implementation note is that although any AECs or BACs applied to the reference species and target will ultimately cancel out, \(\Delta_{\rm f}^{\rm qm}H^{\circ}\) still includes AECs for both the target and the reference species, because the values of \(\Delta_{\rm f}^{\rm qm}H^{\circ}\) for the reference species in the database are augmented with AECs so that they are more reasonable and approximate reference values.

results.input_text: As seen in Table 3, Petersson-type BACs almost always have lower training errors (both MAE and RMSE), while Melius-type BACs more often than not have slightly lower cross-validation errors, and m-BACs always have a smaller change in going from training errors to cross-validation errors. This result suggests that Melius-type BACs might generalize better to types of molecules that are not well represented in the reference set, and that Petersson-type BACs are more likely to be undermined by over-fitting, for p-BACs fit a single parameter to a fairly broad notion of a bond type (e.g., treating C-C bonds in benzene and ethane as the same). In unfortunate scenarios, it is therefore possible that Petersson-type BACs are fitted on a training set containing, for example, C-C bonds with substantial chemical differences from the C-C bond in target species, leading to poor performance in real-life tests and applications. Conversely, Petersson-type BACs may be more susceptible to issues with over-fitting due to their fitting of a single parameter to a broad concept of a bond type (e.g., C-C bonds in benzene and ethane). In unfavorable scenarios, Petersson-type BACs' fitting procedure on a specific training set that includes bonds with noteworthy disparities in chemical structure from target species' bonds can decrease the efficacy of said approach during real-life testing and applications. Moreover, because the cost and performance vary by LOT, a future systemic evaluation and benchmark of more LOTs commonly used in literature for thermochemistry has the high potential to offer deeper insights into choosing the optimal LOT for different types of chemistry.
results.output_text: A key method for achieving high-quality thermochemistry is bond additivity correction. This approach is highly promising and shows a slight advantage over alternative Melius-type BACs. Although the difference in cross-validation errors between Melius-type BACs (m-BAC) and parametrized bond additivity (p-BAC) is not great, especially for higher levels of theory, selecting the optimal level of theory (LOT) for various types of chemistry through systemic evaluation and benchmarking of LOTs commonly used in literature holds the potential to provide even deeper insights and superior generalization performance at a lower cost.

results.output_text: Assessing the efficacy of isodesmic reaction methods necessitates a more in-depth analysis. By selecting a reference set containing a set of species, the approach involves considering each species (\(i\)) independently and regarding its counterparts as the target species in a leave-one-out cross-validation experiment. Specifically, \(\Delta_{\mathrm{f}}^{\mathrm{iso}}H_{i}^{\circ}\) can be calculated for each species using the remaining species in the reference set, and the error for each LOT or reaction class can be computed by subtracting the value of \(\Delta_{\mathrm{f}}^{\mathrm{ref}}H_{i}^{\circ}\) from \(\Delta_{\mathrm{f}}^{\mathrm{iso}}H_{i}^{\circ}\).

results.output_text: However, the IDR (Isodesmic Distance Ratio) method has two complexities to consider. First, it may not be applicable to all species due to inadequate training set problems. This is especially true for higher-order reaction classes, where a limited number of species in the reference set may lack bonds or constraints that are essential for constructing isodesmic reactions. Such scenarios can become increasingly prevalent as reaction class complexity increases. The second complexity is that even when a certain reaction class is specified, the median isodesmic reaction used to calculate the final value for \(\Delta_{\mathrm{f}}^{\mathrm{iso}}H^{\circ}\) may also be a member of a higher-order reaction class, which in turn can affect the calculated energy. To address and analyze these complexities, the present study evaluates the IDR approach through the examination of the performance of LOT A through F, rather than attempting to fit the method for all LOTs.

results.output_text: In contrast to the method proposed by Buerger et al., we considered integrating a metric to directly evaluate the quality of species data within the optimization process. Our approach, therefore, aims to minimize the expected errors of the involved species in the isodesmic reaction. results.input_text: In this work, we implement several approaches for correcting heats of formation obtained through quantum chemistry calculations. Part of this work includes compiling and curating a database (available in the SI) of reference species and thermochemistry data from the literature that contained a diverse set of molecules so that these approaches could be applied to a broad range of molecules. This implementation is available to use with the open-source Arkane software [14], which allows everyone to use these methods and even contribute new parameters for additional levels of theory using the developed application programming interface (API) for fitting parameters and adding new information to the database. Because all of the information needed to fit parameters is stored in the reference species files in the database, it is also possible to replicate our results and regenerate improved corrections.
results.output_text: In this study, we implemented a range of strategies to address the inaccuracies that commonly occur during the computation of heat of formation values through quantum chemistry calculations. As part of our effort, we collated a database of literature-based reference species data and thermochemistry values for a diverse range of molecules that could be applied to a broad spectrum of molecules. This database is provided in the Supplementary Information and may be accessed via the publicly available, open-source Arkane software [14]. Our methods and the associated parameters can be customized using the dedicated application programming interface (API), which also enables users to contribute new parameters or additional levels of theory. The underlying data required to fit parameters is located in the reference species files in the database, which allows for the possibility of replicating our methods and producing updated and improved corrections.

results.input_text: As for the performance of the various methods, Petersson-type and Melius-type BACs show very similar performance, though Melius-type BACs appear to generalize better. Both approaches are a substantial improvement over just using AECs, though, as previously noted in the literature. By comparison, isodesmic reactions do not appear to perform as well as using BACs, unless care is taken to optimize for including reference species that likely have low errors. In this work, we build on the optimization method of Buerger et al., and demonstrate that the performance of automatic IDR is on-par or slightly better than using BACs even with improved objective functions. Although we did not do so here, it would be interesting to compare our improved automatic IDR approach with the pruning approach used by Buerger et al. to achieve a similar end of preferring certain reference species. While the accuracy of many IDRs are comparable to that of BACs, the isodesmic reaction approaches still have the downside that not all species can be calculated using them, as the reference set needs to include enough high-quality species with relevant chemical features.
results.output_text: In terms of their efficiency, Petersson-type and Melius-type BACs display comparable performance, with Melius-type BACs often exhibiting better generalization abilities. However, a significant enhancement over the use of automated error corrections (AECs) is evident. According to previous studies in the literature, isodesmic reactions do not perform as well as BACs in the absence of optimized reference species selection. In this work, Buerger et al.'s optimization approach was expanded, resulting in the presentation of a notably improved automatic isotope-labeling error (IDRE) system that is comparable or even surpasses BACs in performance. Notably, a comparison between the enhanced automatic isotope-labeling error system and the pruning approach employed by Buerger et al. would indeed be intriguing. Nevertheless, despite offering excellent accuracy, the downside of isodesmic reactions is that some species' identification is impossible, given the absence of enough high-quality reference species with relevant chemical features.

results.input_text: With this, in general, we recommend using Melius-type BACs to obtain accurate enthalpies of formation due to its slight advantages. That being said, using Petersson-typeBACs should be viewed as almost equivalent, especially if the target species is well represented in the reference set. Similarly, calculations from isodesmic reactions could also be viewed as almost equivalent if substantial care is taken to choose appropriate reference species, and higher reaction classes are used. Last but not least, given the variance in both cost and performance across different levels of theory, there is a compelling need for a systematic review and benchmarking of enthalpies of formation calculated via LOTs frequently cited in thermochemical literature. Such an effort promises to offer profound insights, guiding researchers in choosing the most suitable LOT for specific chemical contexts, and advancing our progress in efficiently obtaining accurate thermochemical values for a wide variety of molecules.
results.output_text:
In terms of obtaining accurate enthalpies of formation, we recommend primarily utilizing Melius-type bond-addition-correction (BAC) methods due to their slight advantages. However, one should also consider Petersson-type BACs as almost equivalent for calculations involving well-represented target species. Isodesmic reactions can also be equally useful when selecting appropriate reference species and higher reaction classes. Due to the variance in both cost and performance across different levels of theory, there is a pressing need for a systemic review and benchmarking of enthalpies of formation calculated via various LOTs cited in thermochemical literature. Such an effort has the potential to provide crucial insights and enable researchers to select the most suitable LOT for specific chemical scenarios while advancing the field's progress in obtaining accurate thermochemical values for a diverse array of molecules.
